[[Talking to those inside.|NGD6][$charisma +=5]] [[Handling cash and other transactions.|NGD6][$technology +=2]] [[I actually liked bartending, but Chris was better.|NGD6][$bartending +=10, $ss_bartending = true]] [[Making sure the arcade machines were working.|NGD6][$technology +=5]] [[Supervising laser tag, which also meant playing when I wanted to.|NGD6][$combat +=2]] [[Delivering food in the restaurant.|NGD6][$charisma +=2]] [[Watching people fail at skating.|NGD6][$sympathy -=5]] [[Making sure no fights broke out at the bowling alley.|NGD6][$sympathy +=5, $charisma +=5]] [[Supervising everyone and everything.|NGD6][$perception +=5]] [[Sleeping.->NGD6]]<<nobr>> <<set $ss_bartending = true>> <<set $bartending +=20>> <<endnobr>> “It’s a new day, $name.” “Yea, but it’s the same you. And just in case you forgot, I make better drinks than you, that’s why I always make more tips than you,” I choose to remind him. He grimaces and rolls his eyes. Chris loves bartending, almost as much as I did. Though this gave the two of us exciting things to talk about, it also meant that both of us would compete to see who was better. [[Continue|NGD6]]The day goes on, closing time a mere few hours away when suddenly, a large white flash goes off in the distance, catching everyone off guard. My view is blocked by a few buildings, but I can still see the flashes as they continue to go off, each a few minutes apart. It resembles nothing like I’ve ever seen. I want to claim that it’s just fireworks, but the bold lighting of each explosion is nothing like a firework. “What kind of firecrackers are those? And why would someone be setting them off?” I ponder aloud. Watching as another minor explosion goes off. This one didn’t share the same intensity as the others, in fact, it was as if it was a different grade entirely. “Who knows?” Chris says from beside me, sipping on some of the water that he poured himself to combat the two drinks he had. Some of the others seem to agree with Chris and show little interest, continuing on as if the light had never happened. Perhaps it really was just fireworks. I look in the direction again, but when I see nothing, I shove it from my brain and continue my work. <<link [img[images/divider.png]] >><</link>> ''Meanwhile, a couple streets away . . .'' With a disgusted grimace, the woman gathers and spits out the wad of blood forming in her mouth. The metallic taste prolongs the sneer, and for a minute, she desperately craves the taste of water. But only for a minute. The act was for nothing as more blood gathers merely in its place, as well as the steady stream of blood arching down her cut cheek. “For once in your life, Sydero, listen to me. Stop this, now,” a proud character with a blade orders, his voice wavering. Even when he was trying to sound like he was in command, it still came off as begging. The woman called Sydero rises to her feet and cocks her head, wiping a mix of sweat and blood from her brow. “Done playing already?” she inquires. Before her opponent can reply, she lunges towards him, half of her body shrouded in a dark grey mist. He bites the inside of his lip, involuntarily drawing blood. He had no choice but to match her ferocity, lest he wanted to be killed. The two figures struck against one another for what seems like the tenth time, a weak bright light appearing before flickering and then finally disappearing. Both of their bodies were pushed back by the force, and they again find themselves on opposite sides of the street, glaring at one another. [[Continue->NGD6_1]]“Whoa,” he starts, putting his hand to his chest as he looks down at his shorts, “take notes, don’t hate.” “No one is hating, trust me.” I snicker as I push him playfully. Chris loves bartending, I, on the other hand, didn’t feel so strongly. I would rather be ... [[Talking to those inside.|NGD6][$charisma +=5]] [[Handling cash and other transactions.|NGD6][$technology +=2]] [[Making sure the arcade machines were working.|NGD6][$technology +=5]] [[Supervising laser tag, which also meant playing when I wanted to.|NGD6][$combat +=2]] [[Delivering food in the restaurant.|NGD6][$charisma +=2]] [[Watching people fail at skating.|NGD6][$sympathy -=5]] [[Making sure no fights broke out at the bowling alley.|NGD6][$sympathy +=5, $charisma +=5]] [[Supervising everyone and everything.|NGD6][$perception +=5]] [[Sleeping.->NGD6]]“This is getting us nowhere! We’re doing nothing but bringing attention to ourselves,” he points out. “Is that your way of surrendering?” Sydero questions, flicking dirt out from underneath her fingernails. She looks over at him with an uninterested raised brow, knowing the expression and lack of care would anger the figure further. “You selfish brat,” he growls, and Sydero’s back stiffens. She turns to face him fully, waiting for him to continue. “You know damn well why I can’t give you what you want, but still you search for it. If you love her, you’ll let her go, you know she’s safer with me.” “Says who exactly?” she shouts back, “you? You’re on the opposite side of the river from me, but you’re still sinking in the same type of boat. You just refuse to patch the holes because you’re telling yourself they don’t exist.” He opens his mouth to respond, but she cuts him off with a warning growl. “Here’s a promise. Either give her to me or die, damn the consequences.” The figure freezes as he glares at the woman in front of him, his eyes searching hers. If he failed to see the seriousness in her words, he only had to look into her color-shifting eyes. The amber color was slowly fading, dribbling down as if something was causing it to melt out of her iris. Replacing it was a bloody red whose brilliance was only rivaled by the slightly darker crimson color that edged in at the edges. The whites of her eyes disappeared along with her pupil, leaving nothing but the deadly shades of red. Silence continues as anger courses freely through Sydero’s body. The figure trembles as he replays her words. This battle wasn’t the first, but no matter how many times they had met, she had never threatened him with death. “Is this what it has come to?” he asks, shaking as a white mist begins to surround him, similar to the black mist surrounding her. “You threaten to kill me?” Sydero doesn’t answer. She meant her words, and if forced to, would carry them out. But they also killed a part of her. She knew that going through with her threat would mean no return from the place she would go. Their eyes meet, hers a sea of blood and death, and his a pleading proud arctic blue. “If you don’t surrender her, then so be it.” It was as if all the air in the area had been sucked out, giving room to an oppressive atmosphere, perfect for an explosion. “Then so be it,” he whispers and the two surge towards one another in perfect accord. Their mists grow into crackles of raw energy, crimson and artic sparks shooting off of their body and ricocheting off of the streets and sidewalks. The figures meet. [[Continue->NGD6_2]]<<nobr>> <<set $nerve -=10>> <<endnobr>> <<link [img[images/divider.png]] >><</link>> I jump at both the sound of an explosion, and the feeling of it rocking the ground. Chris does the same, falling backward into one of the shelves, inconsequently causing some of the bottles to fall from their perch. But that is the least of my worries at the moment. The pool erupts into screams as everyone tries to figure out what is going on, scrambling to get away. I gaze in the direction of the previously perceived fireworks, seeing the cloud of smoke that rises from the area. “The hell is going on? Did something blow up, like a pipe or something?” Chris asks no one in particular, especially seeing that both of us were the same amount of clueless. “Did someone call the cops, the fire department?” I hear someone ask and a chorus of yes’s, sprinkled around the pool, answer him. “We’re going to close up early,” my manager states, bounding towards us. We nod in agreement and begin the long and arduous job of rounding up a bunch of freaked out and upset customers, as well as cleaning everything up. We finish earlier than usual but are no less jumpy when we end. Chris and I bounce ideas off of each other, trying to deduce what could have happened and guessing when the news would cover it. <<if $keycar is true>>\ “Who did this?” we both hear someone scream and see Mr. Pinsky standing beside what I perceive to be his car, pointing at the side. “Who keyed my car?” No one says anything, only a few trying to calm him down and tell him that it was probably some random teens. “I’m checking those cameras!” he shouts before getting into his car and driving off in a rush. Chris pushes me gently, raising an eyebrow, hoping I would confirm his suspicions. “I’m not admitting to anything,” I smirk, and he chuckles softly, nodding his head. <</if>>\ [[Continue->NGD6_3]]The two of us say our goodbyes, and I get into my car, realizing that I forgot my wallet inside. Thankfully I was given a key to the place, and I quickly run back into the back room to grab it. I’m locking the door back up when I hear a strange sound coming from a nearby path on the other side of the building. I walk a few meters, gazing down the path that was there for no other reason but to help someone get to the pool faster. I hear the sound again, and I shift from one foot to the other uncomfortably. [[Call out.]] [[Try to figure out the noise.]] [[Shine a flashlight down the path.]]<<nobr>> <<set $daring +=3>> <<endnobr>> “Hello?” I call out, taking a few more steps before pausing. This was definitely starting to look like the start of some scary movie, starring yours truly. I hear the sound again but hear it clearly this time - a moan. [[Continue->NGD6_4]]I stand there silently, attempting to figure out exactly what the sound was before deciding on what to do. It takes a few minutes, but I finally hear it again and make out what it is - a moan. [[Continue->NGD6_4]]I take my phone out and go to the flashlight app, shining it down the path. This was definitely starting to look like the start of some scary movie, starring yours truly. I hear the sound again but hear it clearly this time - a moan. [[Continue->NGD6_4]]My mind begins to play cruel pranks on me, choosing to remind me of the images in my dreams. I jump at nothing, believing that a shadow had passed behind me. “Hello? Are you okay? I’m here to help.” I receive another moan in response, this one a bit louder and movement follows. I approach the movement, and find myself standing near a trashcan, a young woman lies there hardly breathing. <<if $medical < 10>>\ “Aw crap. Are you okay, miss?” I reach out and lightly touch her arm, hearing her grumble under my touch but otherwise receive no response. I notice her body shaking significantly, perhaps the result of her having a seizure. <<else>>\ “Aw crap. Are you okay, miss?” I reach out and lightly grab her arm, checking for a pulse. I'm unable to find one but there could be a number of reasons for there not being one. I then place my phone under her nose, watching as a bit of condensation appears on the surface. She was still breathing normal so that was a good sign. I do a quick search of her body to make sure she's not bleeding, and to make sure nothing is broken. If she was, then moving her would be unwise. <</if>>\ “Hey, I’m going to help you, alright? I’m taking you to the hospital.” I bend down and attempt to pick her up, finding that she’s not the lightest person in the world. I’m able to help her to my car, freezing once I get there. [[Put her in the passenger seat.]] [[Put her in the backseat.]] [[Put her in the trunk.]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero +=2>> <<set $sympathy +=5>> <<set $daring +=2>> <<endnobr>> It was the only logical option. And if there was a chance that she’d wake up and stab me, I would at least be able to see it coming. She might also tell me what happened to her if she ever gains consciousness. [[Continue->NGD6_5]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero -=2>> <<set $sympathy +=5>> <<set $daring -=3>> <<endnobr>> Honestly, I wasn’t a fan of having a complete stranger in the seat right beside me. I imagined her waking up and, out of panic, attacking me instantly. Something traumatic could have befallen her, or she could be a psycho, a psycho having a seizure and needing medical attention. It seems like the safest place to put her, and so I put her in the backseat, nodding to myself as I go back to the driver’s seat. [[Continue->NGD6_5]]<<nobr>> <<set $trunk = true>> <<set $sydero -=5>> <<set $sympathy -=5>> <<set $daring -=5>> <<endnobr>> It was a suspicious thing to do, especially moving from the darkened path to my car with an unconscious woman in tow. But I wasn’t about to trust a passed-out stranger and the idea of having her anywhere in the car made me shake. I just didn’t want her sitting anywhere close to me. I would be careful not to go flying over any bumps and to park away from prying eyes, but I wasn’t putting her in the passengers seat or backseat. [[Continue->NGD6_5]]<<if $cmajor is "Nursing">>\ Once I arrive at the hospital, I enter with the woman, trying to make my struggle look as obvious as possible in hopes of getting a nurse to run to my aid. Finally, a familiar nurse sees me and rushes over. “$name? What happened?” Nurse Hillary asks, one of the nurses I knew fairly well thanks to my volunteer hours at the hospital. She was also one of the nurses I would be shadowing for my future internship. “I don’t know, I found her like this on a path near The Alley. No bruising, bleeding, or broken bones. I think she's in shock though.” Hillary hails another woman, this one I'm not familiar with, and after relaying what I told her to the woman, rushes the woman away on a gurney. “Thank you $name, I need to get a quick statement from you before you go though.” This was to be expected, especially seeing that she could’ve been assaulted or raped. I nod in compliance, and Hillary begins to go through the motions. She allows me to go after asking all of the questions needed and I head home. <<else>>\ Once I arrive at the hospital, I enter with the woman, trying to make my struggle look as obvious as possible in hopes of getting a nurse to run to my aid. Finally, a nurse sees me and rushes over. “What happened?” “I don’t know, I found her like this on a path near the building where I work. I think she was having a seizure or something earlier.” The nurse hails another woman and after speaking in medical jargon, rushes the woman away on a gurney. “Thank you, but I do need to ask you some questions.” This was to be expected, especially seeing that she could’ve been assaulted or raped. I nod in compliance, and she begins to go through the motions. The nurse allows me to go after asking all of the questions needed and I head home. <</if>>\ I check the time as soon as I get in the car, also shocked that my uncle hadn’t texted me since I had promised to come over and see him after work. I send him a quick text, promising to come by tomorrow. Finally being able to drive home is a relief I never knew I needed. I take several deep breaths as I go, thinking back on everything that had occurred. My mind goes from my talk with my therapist, to the fireworks and explosion, and then to finding the woman unconscious on the path. I roll down the window and take multiple breaths. I just need to drive home. Tomorrow, I was back to the regular grind of my boring, insignificant life. [[Act Two->EP1-Act Two]]<<set $moneypromise = false>> <<set $ride = false>> <<set $knowher = false>> <<link [img[images/acttwo.png]] >><</link>> The next day, I sit in the library. Before me rests a series of books needed to complete my final essay for the semester. Involuntarily, my eyes gaze at the draft resting beside me, no longer recognizable due to the bright red markings and comments that adorn it. At first, I doubted this paper was even mine. But one look at the upper left-hand corner and I had my answer. Sitting nicely, void of that wretched red pen, in Times New Roman, 12-point font, double-spaced, was my name. That was probably the only thing that wasn’t crossed out or accompanied by that dreaded red slash. I couldn’t, and still can’t, grasp how I got such a bad grade on this paper. This was the first paper that I had done on time, no procrastination. [[I pulled out all the stops for it.]] [[I did it piece by piece.]] [[Yea, no. I definitely procrastinated this essay.]]<<nobr>> <<set $stubborn -=5>> <<endnobr>> Visiting the library, grabbing tons of sources that I actually used and even grabbing some of the reference books. Some of those same books were with me again, mocking me. [[Continue->NGD7]]<<nobr>> <<set $stubborn -=5>> <<endnobr>> I did a little each day, taking about two hours out of my day to write. I finished quickly doing it that way, but apparently, it didn’t make a difference. [[Continue->NGD7]]<<nobr>> <<set $stubborn +=5>> <<endnobr>> It wasn’t horrible procrastination; I didn’t do it the night before or anything. But for me to write an essay, I had to be in the mindset. It just so happened that I wasn’t in the mindset for this particular one until a day or two before it was due. [[Continue->NGD7]]I glance over at Chris who had decided to join me. He was more concerned with his phone than studying, a fact that wasn’t that shocking. If one chose to judge Chris based off of his appearance, they would conclude that he was your typical college frat boy. This being brought on by his brown wavy, bordering on unkempt at times, hair, light blue almost grey eyes, and a beard that transitioned between stubble and heavy throughout the year. Adding to that was him being a prominent member of the tennis team and having an unhealthy obsession with junk food and working out. But despite this, he was incredibly and annoyingly smart. He was the type of student that didn’t have to study to get good grades, and when he did study, well just hope that you were sitting beside him cos he cared little about others copying his test. “Damnit!” Chris shouts, cringing when he remembers where he was, “I can’t win this level.” I gaze over at his screen, but the game doesn't look familiar. “What are you studying anyway?” Chris asks, putting his phone down and turning to me entirely. “Trying to get this final essay done.” “Oh right, the one in Professor Perfection’s class. Did you ever check out the news and read up about that explosion?” I shake my head, forgetting all about that when I woke up. “Cops and firefighters say an underground gas line blew up. No one was there, and besides some houses taking the brunt of it, everything was fine. That neighborhood is completely abandoned anyway, so the city doesn’t really care all that much.” “Do they want to fix it?” “Probably, but I’m sure they’re not going to be working their butts off to do it.” I nod my head and go back to studying, hearing Chris get impatient with the lack of attention probably. The thought causes me to smirk. “Alright, I’m going to go to the coffee shop and get something real quick. Do you want your usual?” [[“Tea? Yea.”->NGD7_1]] [[“Definitely, bring me my coffee.”->NGD7_1]] [[“Naw, just a bagel for me.”->NGD7_1]] [[“I’m good with a fruit parfait.”->NGD7_1]] [[“A bottled juice please.”->NGD7_1]] [[“Just water.”->NGD7_1]]“I know what you want,” Chris huffs with a roll of his eyes, “I’ve known you since you walked into my domain.” He opens his arms as if declaring the entire library his. “And yet you still have the tendency to ask me stupid questions.” “Blah blah blah,” he laughs, punching me lightly before walking off towards the nearby coffee shop. <<if $int is "both" or $int is "men">>\ [[I watch him go with a light blush.]] <</if>>\ <<if $int is "both" or $int is "men">>\ [[I eye him hungrily as he walks off.]] <</if>>\ [[I smile and then turn my attention back to my work.]] [[I roll my eyes before going back to my work.]]<<nobr>> <<set $CRomance +=1>> <<set $chris +=3>> <<endnobr>> I can’t help the smile that spreads across my face or the blush that spreads due to both him and the feelings stirring within me. Indeed, we’ve known each other since I came to college, but he knew nothing of my sprouting feelings for him. I always admired him and thought him handsome, but the feeling of wanting more never came about until last year. [[Continue->NGD7_2]]<<nobr>> <<set $CRomance +=1>> <<set $chris +=3>> <<endnobr>> My eyes roam his body slowly, taking in everything that I can due to him actually wearing clothes. I smirk at the thought and turn, biting the inside of my cheek. Indeed, we’ve known each other since I came to college, but he knew nothing of my sprouting feelings and wants for him. I always admired him and thought him handsome, but the feeling of wanting more never came about until last year. [[Continue->NGD7_2]]<<nobr>> <<set $chris +=5>> <<endnobr>> I smile after him before turning my attention back to work. I had a handful of people that I considered friends. I was social, but not as social as many others. Now that I think about it, I have no idea how Chris ended up being the one person that I could consider as my closest friend. We were in the same class and forced into becoming partners, and it took off from there. [[Continue->NGD7_2]]<<nobr>> <<set $chris -=5>> <<endnobr>> I roll my eyes after him before turning my attention back to work. I had a handful of people that I considered friends. I was social, but not as social as many others. Now that I think about it, I have no idea how Chris ended up being the one person that I could consider as my closest friend. Of course, we had our disagreements, a handful that always leaves me wondering why we were friends in the first place. [[Continue->NGD7_2]]<<if $cmajor is "Nursing">>\ Chris comes back with what I requested, and I continue to do my research. My attention is taken off of it for a minute when my phone rings, the hospital's ID pops up. “Hello?” I answer. “Hello, $name?” Ms. Alanna asks, putting on her professional voice. It always tickles me, hearing how formal she was over the phone, yet how casual and carefree she was in person. “Hey Ms. Alanna, is everything okay?” “I’m calling about the young lady that you found and brought in last night.” “Is she okay?” “She’s fine, just some scattered bruising. She actually regained consciousness this morning. But that’s not the reason I called you. The police were unable to get anything from her, and we were hoping that she would talk to you since you were the one who found and helped her.” <<else>>\ Chris comes back with what I requested, and I continue to do my research. My attention is taken off of it for a minute when my phone rings, an unknown number popping up. “Hello?” I answer cautiously. “Hello. This is the Saint Thomas Hospital. Is this $name?” a professional woman asks on the other side. “Yes, this is.” “I’m calling considering the young lady that you found and brought in last night.” “Is she okay?” “She’s fine, just some scattered bruising. She actually regained consciousness this morning. But that’s not the reason I called you. The police were unable to get anything from her, and we were hoping that she would talk to you since you were the one who found and helped her.” <</if>>\ “Yea sure, should I come by now?” “Whenever you have time before five o’clock. Thank you.” And with that I hang up the phone. I was able to get one paragraph done and needed a break anyway, might as well go now since the campus was closer to the hospital than my job. I begin to pack up my stuff, Chris raising a brow. “Where are you going?” [[Tell him about the girl.]] [[Lie about what happened.]]<<nobr>> <<set $honesty +=10>> <<set $chris +=2>> <<set $chrishonesty = true>> <<endnobr>> “I found this girl unconscious yesterday on the path towards the pool beside The Alley. They want to see if she’ll talk to me.” “Why?” “She’s not talking to the cops. Guess they think she’ll talk to me.” “Oh, sounds interesting, maybe she’s like some undercover detective with amnesia.” “You and that imagination of yours.” “Right. I should definitely write a children’s book.” I say my farewells and head to the hospital. [[Continue->NGD7_3]]<<nobr>> <<set $honesty -=10>> <<endnobr>> “My uncle needs me to do some errands for him, simple stuff but he doesn’t want to do them.” “Sounds about right?” Chris chuckles and waves me off. [[Continue->NGD7_3]] <<if $cmajor is "Nursing">>\ I arrive at the hospital sometime later, weaving my way in between patients and doctors and nurses, and really anyone else that happens to be walking around. I make a beeline for Alanna's desk. She types furiously at her keyboard, her eyes never leaving the screen, even when she stops to sip her coffee. "Alanna," I chime, leaning dramatically on the desk. “$name, you made it. We can speak later if you want, but here's the the room number.” I thank her before departing and make my way to the appropriate room, spotting two nurses standing outside of it. One, I didn't know, but the other was Hillary. “Excuse me?” “Ah, $name, thanks for coming, she still hasn’t said a word to anyone since she’s been awake. We don’t know her name, age, or if she even has a family. We’re hoping, since you helped her out that she'll tell you.” <<else>>\ I arrive at the hospital sometime later, weaving my way in between patients and doctors and nurses, and really anyone else that happens to be walking around. I make a beeline for the busy appearing receptionist. “Can I help you?” she asks, raising a brow but otherwise not giving me any other kind of attention. “Yes, I’m here for ...” I soon realize that I don’t even know the woman’s name or the name of the nurse that had called me. “I’m $name Roe. I received a call to come by to talk to a young woman that I helped in the other day.” The receptionist nods in understanding and hands me a small sticky note, on it rests a room number. I thank her before departing and making my way to the appropriate room, spotting two nurses standing outside of it. One, I immediately recognize from yesterday. “Excuse me?” “Ah, $name, am I right?” I nod. “Thanks for coming, she still hasn’t said a word to anyone since she’s been awake. We don’t know her name, age, or if she even has a family. We’re hoping, since you helped her out that she'll tell you.” <</if>>\ “I’ll try my best.” The nurses nod and let me into the room. The sound of me entering perks the woman up, and I can see curiosity blazing in her amber colored eyes. We look each other over with interest, me just taking the chance to take in her appearance, and she trying to figure out the reason for my presence. There’s a glimmer in her eyes and bewilderment covers her face. She has loose wavy black hair, currently pulled into a messy bun. The color contrasted yet went incredibly well up against her light olive skin which is riddled with bruises and a series of long-aged looking scars. Two prominent ones rest on her face, one near her right brow, and the other resting against her nose. Some of the other scars were still the color of fresh blood, causing me to wonder if she allowed the staff here to touch her at all. But, try as I might, my attention kept going back to her eyes. They are an intense amber color that seems like they could shift to either a more brownish shade or go straight red. Even under the strained fluorescent light of the hospital, they had a bright golden tinge to them. But they weren’t soft or welcoming. Instead, they penetrated my entire being, slicing past any defenses I might’ve had up and eliminated any and all resistance. [[Continue staring.]] [[Say hi.]]I attempt to pull myself away from her gaze but feel it impossible, part of me wonders if I even wanted to. My body relaxes on its own as I continue to stare. Only when she clears her throat do I realize what I had been doing, and I stiffen, clearing mine as well. [[Continue->NGD7_4]]“Hi,” I say and give her a slight wave. She raises an eyebrow as if surprised that I could speak and gives me another once-over, before meeting my eyes again. [[Continue ->NGD7_4]]“Do I know you?” she questions. “Um, probably not. My name is $name Roe, I was the one who found you and brought you here.” <<if $trunk>>\ “Oh, so it was your trunk that I was stuffed in last night?” she asks, cocking her head to the side and her eyes narrowing. “Wait, you know about that?” “I was drifting, I wasn’t unconscious. Well, I wasn’t until you took a flying leap over that one pothole.” “Yea sorry for that. But hey, it’s better than that path, right?” <</if>>\ “You should’ve left me there,” she mumbles, finally breaking eye contact with me, looking outside the window now. “Well then,” I start after clearing my throat, “how are you feeling?” “Why does it matter?” “Look, I’m just trying to please the nurses here. They say you won’t talk to anybody and –” “And they brought you along in hopes that I’ll spill my guts out to you, huh? Wow, and I thought they were supposed to be smart.” I continue to stare at her, this wasn’t exactly how I pictured this going. I didn’t expect her to blurt out her life problems to me, but I did expect her to give me the gist of what happened to her, and how she ended up near my job. <<if $trunk>>\ But even I found it hard to completely trust someone who thought it a good idea to stuff me in their trunk. <</if>>\ “At least give me your name.” “No,” she says in an overly aggressive tone. [[Grill her for more information.]] [[Try and guess her name.]] [[Ask if she's okay.]] [[Give up.]]<<nobr>> <<set $stubborn +=2>> <<set $sydero -=3>> <<set $serious +=10>> <<endnobr>> “What happened to you?” I question. She raises a brow at my tone, no doubt trying to figure out why I would ask such thing, especially since she didn’t give me something as simple as her name. “How did you end up on the path? Any family members?” “What are you? An undercover cop? Who did you say you were again?” “I’m just trying to help you by figuring out what happened.” “Nothing that concerns you in the slightest. You don't know me, let's keep it that way.” “Now then, if you’re done asking questions.” She swings her legs around and gets to her feet, wobbling before balancing herself. She approaches me and though she keeps distance between us, looks me over in interest. “What are you anyway?” “Um, a struggling college student?” I tell her, though I say so with confusion mixed in with my tone. She narrows her brows, and something causes her eyes to light up in realization. She shakes her head, moving whatever was on her mind to the back. She doesn’t say anything else, just walking towards the door with a purpose. I follow behind her, shocked to find that no one tries to stop us. That is until we get to the bottom floor and we're approached. “Wait, did she say anything to you? Why is she leaving with you, do you know her?” [["She's my best friend's girlfriend."]] [["She’s a classmate, only recognized her today."]] [["I don't know her, but I know her brother."]] [["No, she just chose to leave when I did."]] <<if $cmajor is "Nursing">>\ [["I was going to give her a few tests."]] <</if>>\ [[Don't answer.]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero +=3>> <<set $stubborn +=2>> <<set $serious -=10>> <<endnobr>> “Amelia? No, um you don’t look like you’d have a common name to be honest. But then I guess reverse psychology would mean you do.” She raises an eyebrow towards me but doesn’t say anything. “Alright, rapid fire. Lyndsay. Becky. Tya. Connor. Kylie. Kalani. Toni. Neri. Daisha. Niaja. Tianna. Sushi?” “Sushi?” she questions, trying her hardest to hide the smile trying to appear. “You were giving me these weird looks, so I just said something totally out of the way.” She opens her mouth to answer but then closes it, appearing like she had remembered who she was talking to. She scrunches her nose up and sends me a conflicted look, filled mostly with disapproval, though I wonder if it’s more for herself than for me. “Now then, if you’re done asking questions.” She swings her legs around and gets to her feet, wobbling before balancing herself. She stares at me with that same interest in her eyes before shrugging and nodding her head. Though I’m not sure, I believe she is nodding to say that she’s fine. “Now then, if you’re done asking questions.” She swings her legs around and gets to her feet, wobbling before balancing herself. Why is she leaving with you, do you know her?” [["She's my best friend's girlfriend."]] [["She’s a classmate, only recognized her today."]] [["I don't know her, but I know her brother."]] [["No, she just chose to leave when I did."]] <<if $cmajor is "Nursing">>\ [["I was going to give her a few tests."]] <</if>>\ [[Don't answer.]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero +=5>> <<endnobr>> I scoff in both defeat and disbelief. If she didn't want my help then I wouldn't give it to her. I didn't know her and she didn't know me, so I fail to see why I should continue pushing her. Plus, whatever had happened to her was her problem. They called me here to see if I could get her to open up, I can't. “Now then, if you’re done asking questions.” She swings her legs around and gets to her feet, wobbling before balancing herself. She approaches me and though she keeps distance between us, looks me over in interest. “What are you anyway?” “Um, a struggling college student?” I tell her, though I say so with confusion mixed in with my tone. She narrows her brows, and something causes her eyes to light up in realization. She shakes her head, moving whatever was on her mind to the back. She doesn’t say anything else, just walking towards the door with a purpose. I follow behind her, shocked to find that no one tries to stop us. That is until we get to the bottom floor and we're approached. “Wait, did she say anything to you? Why is she leaving with you, do you know her?” [["She's my best friend's girlfriend."]] [["She’s a classmate, only recognized her today."]] [["I don't know her, but I know her brother."]] [["No, she just chose to leave when I did."]] <<if $cmajor is "Nursing">>\ [["I was going to give her a few tests."]] <</if>>\ [[Don't answer.]]I call out to the figure, hoping that my voice would cause some type of reaction. I get nothing, not even a twitch. The forest seems to have heard me though. It was silent before, but that was a hopeful silence. A silence that caused one to believe that if they continued on, then they would soon hear the birds and frogs, and the river. This silence, it was one that haunted places, that watched those who trespassed and followed them like a stalking predator. I gaze around when I spot the body move, suddenly jerking up into the air. The branches tighten its grasp on my uncle’s limp form. “$name, how are you?” my uncle asks but his mouth moves lazily. The branches drag random limbs in erratic directions. The entire scene reminds me of a puppet show, regardless of the spine-chilling atmosphere. I open my mouth to answer, or question, when the body surges towards me, my uncle’s head lazily tilting to the side. It was impossible for the figure to have any bones in his body, judging off the way that his neck was rolling from one side to the other. The body stops short directly in front of me. He grinds his teeth, and his eyes move up and down my body. “You’re fine. Not dead, unlike me. I’m dead!” he screams the last part, the branches pulling him back harshly. His leg gives out, and he stumbles, but his support doesn’t let him follow. It swiftly picks him back up, reprimanding him in the process. “Must be nice,” he sings, chuckling as he sways from side to side. “$name, what were you thinking when you saw my dead body?” [["Oh shit."]] [["I wasn't thinking anything."]] [["Eh, the usual, damn."]] [["Just tell me how to get out of here."]] [["Why does it matter?"]]I search the ground for anything that I could use, finding only a sizeable stick. I test the weight to decide how much strength would be needed. Once I figure this out, I toss the stick at the figure. I expect the figure to dart out of the way or to even twitch in irritation. It does none of the above, it doesn’t move at all. So, I decide to throw something else. I find another stick, some ways off from where I discovered the first. This one is smaller but will deliver the same results. I toss it towards the motionless body, jumping when the immobile body suddenly moves, jerking into the air and rotating towards me. The branches tighten its grasp on my uncle’s limp form. “$name, how are you?” my uncle asks but his mouth moves lazily. The branches drag random limbs in erratic directions. The entire scene reminds me of a puppet show, regardless of the spine-chilling atmosphere. I open my mouth to answer, or question, when the body surges towards me, my uncle’s head lazily tilting to the side. It was impossible for the figure to have any bones in his body, judging off the way that his neck was rolling from one side to the other. The body stops short directly in front of me. He grinds his teeth, and his eyes move up and down my body. “You’re fine. Not dead, unlike me. I’m dead!” he screams the last part, the branches pulling him back harshly. His leg gives out, and he stumbles, but his support doesn’t let him follow. It swiftly picks him back up, reprimanding him in the process. “Must be nice,” he sings, chuckling as he sways from side to side. “$name, what were you thinking when you saw my dead body?” [["Oh shit."]] [["I wasn't thinking anything."]] [["Eh, the usual, damn."]] [["Just tell me how to get out of here."]] [["Why does it matter?"]]I approach the figure. This was a dream; therefore, I was somehow controlling all of this. Furthermore, the myth about dying in a dream leads to death in real life is just that, a myth. Or was it? I once believed that the supernatural was just a bunch of stories and apparently that was false. My first few steps yield no response. The still figure remains stationary, and only the branches, intertwining through the limp body, is the only sign of movement. I continue forward, almost close enough to touch the immobile body, when it suddenly jerks up into the air. The branches tighten its grasp on my uncle’s limp form. “$name, how are you?” my uncle asks but his mouth moves lazily. The branches drag random limbs in erratic directions. The entire scene reminds me of a puppet show, regardless of the spine-chilling atmosphere. I open my mouth to answer, or question, when the body surges towards me, my uncle’s head lazily tilting to the side. It was impossible for the figure to have any bones in his body, judging off the way that his neck was rolling from one side to the other. The body stops short directly in front of me. He grinds his teeth, and his eyes move up and down my body. “You’re fine. Not dead, unlike me. I’m dead!” he screams the last part, the branches pulling him back harshly. His leg gives out, and he stumbles, but his support doesn’t let him follow. It swiftly picks him back up, reprimanding him in the process. “Must be nice,” he sings, chuckling as he sways from side to side. “$name, what were you thinking when you saw my dead body?” [["Oh shit."]] [["I wasn't thinking anything."]] [["Eh, the usual, damn."]] [["Just tell me how to get out of here."]] [["Why does it matter?"]]I pick up a rock and launch it towards them. It strikes one of the crows right in the chest, sending him falling to the ground. The others don’t gaze after their fallen compatriot, they don’t move at all. The crow that I had hit uprights itself and flies back to the original perch. The only sign of it ever being hit is a growing blood stain on its chest. Like the others, it goes back to staring at me, ignoring whatever pain it might be in. I don’t understand why, but my heart rate picks up rapidly under their gaze. Each second that passes by sees my fear escalating. Sweat dribbles down the side of my face, my hands grow clammy, my legs stiff. The crows give nothing away, nothing in their behavior has changed. The only variable that has changed is me. I pick up another rock, unchecked rage coursing through me. As soon as I have the rock in my palm, a flash of black appears in front of me. I shriek as the crows fly around my head, cawing and pecking at me. The pain intensifies with every peck, and regardless of how many times I try to scare them away, they are unyielding. I screech as the pecks become cleverly placed: the cheek, the chest, the mouth, and the eye. I scream as loud as I can but find it to be frivolous, death sings my name. [[Continue->A1]] “What do you want?” I question. Did I truly expect for them to chirp out a reply? For them to aid me as if this was some sort of fantasy tale? If I did, I was sorely put out by their lack of answering, or even signs that they acknowledged my voice. They each continue to stare, their eyes piercing me. I’m about to question them again when my eyes make contact with each crow, the words are lost. I choke on my thoughts, on the words that I was about to say. I suddenly feel very sick in my body, as if everything about me was wrong. It was an out of body experience on another level. I felt connected to my soul and felt that the body that we were inhabiting was wrong, was diseased in some way. I crumble to the ground, gasping for air, although my lungs were filled with it. I could still breathe fine, but it felt like I was suffocating. Six eyes stare down at me. Six crows glare at me as the forest closes in. [[Continue->A1]]I turn on my heel and march the other way, curious about the components of the forest that were actually alive. I hear a stream and go in the general direction, noticing a large oak tree with squirrels running up its trunk. This area was so much different than the last, alive with the feeling of hope. I take a deep breath in when I begin to smell a putrid odor. I open my eyes and find myself in the middle of a desolate clearing. Residing on each barren perch is a crow, six in all. They stare at me with bloodshot eyes. Another sniff and I realize that the odor is being secreted from them. Upon closer inspection I find their wings made of tar, melting under an unseen sun. The smell grows as they decompose, leaving nothing but empty husks. But nevertheless, dead or alive . . . Six crows stare down at me. [[Continue->A1]]Something light tickles my nose, waking me from the dream. My eyes flutter open, but my vision is blurred. In front of me I see nothing but a gray bundle mess, a bundle that happens to be moving. I hear it produce a squeak and realization hits me. Jumping back, I swat the mouse off from my face. Consequently, I end up on the floor, my eyes darting from one dark crevice to the next. Where the hell was I? <<if $uncledead>>\ Weathered wallpaper, torn curtains, and the retreating mouse remind me of everything that had taken place. It all rushes back to me in a flood of unbelievability. The supernatural world is real. My uncle is dead, and his house probably mostly burned down. I was on the run with a mysterious witch. <<else>>\ Weathered wallpaper, torn curtains, and the retreating mouse remind me of everything that had taken place. It all rushes back to me in a flood of unbelievability. The supernatural world is real. My uncle is safe in a hotel. I was on the run with a mysterious witch. <</if>>\ <<if $uncledead>>\ [[I can't believe all this happened.]] <</if>>\ [[Whelp, here comes another panic attack.]] [[This was going to take longer than I thought.]] [[I was okay, this circumstance isn't okay, but I'll be okay.]] [[Shit, that crap seriously happened?!]] [[Deep breaths.]]The words aren’t completely out of my mouth when he laughs loudly. His body whips around, and the branches aid him in walking towards the edge of the forest. The way he goes reminds me faintly of how a child would play with their dolls. Walking was deemed unnecessary, and instead, they would move the doll through hops. “I was thinking about how I finally was able to now get away from you.” “You’re not real. So, whatever you say isn’t real.” “You’re going to die,” he chimes in, his figure disappearing until the fog swallows him. The trees disappear as well, leaving only one tree in its place. The tree stands around seven feet and is probably the thickest tree I’ve seen to date. Ritualistic images are carved into the tree, appearing like five figures sitting on top of one another. Only the figure at the bottom has thick branches that branch out upwards into lankier, more wicked appearing branches. The tree holds no eyes, but I feel it watching me from all sides. I hear faint whispering, as if it was condemning me to a fate I knew nothing about. My eyes follow the branches up, higher and higher until they stop at an intricate pattern. Though I know I have never seen such a design, a strange familiarity with it overwhelms me. I reach out to touch it, growing closer and closer. The whispers get louder, the forest awakes, the pattern stares back at me, and the limbs slither towards its prey. The whispers get louder, the forest awakes, the pattern stares back at me, and the limbs slither towards its prey. [[Continue->A1]] <<nobr>> <<set $nerve -=2>> <<endnobr>> My poor uncle. He didn’t deserve this, he didn’t deserve any of this crap. But I guess that was a tale that most people would, and could, sing. Losing him, on top of everything else, I just feel like I was being hit with multiple shocks. This stress was worse than anything that has happened in the past. I stand up and stretch, feeling a crick in my neck and the soreness in my back. I was surprised an abandoned house had a bed still, let alone a mattress – no matter how hard. I felt like falling back to the ground though, living the rest of my existence there. It had to be better than feeling each and every ache that my body currently held. [[Continue->A1_1]]<<nobr>> <<set $nerve -=2>> <<endnobr>> I was a college student, I was already breaking down and screaming into my pillow every night. I was struggling enough with juggling college, a job, and the trauma from my past. And now this. Oh geez. My heart was beating frantically, and I feel a cold chill lay itself on me, though I was sweating and felt like I was about to have a heat flash. I need to breathe, desperately. I do some breathing exercises, finally feeling more like myself. I stand up and stretch, feeling a crick in my neck and the soreness in my back. I was surprised an abandoned house had a bed still, let alone a mattress – no matter how hard. I felt like falling back to the ground though, living the rest of my existence there. It had to be better than feeling each and every ache that my body currently held. [[Continue->A1_1]]I don’t know how easy I thought this would all be before, but I definitely wasn’t entirely okay with this. Truthfully, I believe I’ve earned that. Cliché as it is, my world has been flipped upside down, dribbled down a court, and then the shooter widely misses. My world was the ball that never gets found, doomed to live out its life in the backyard of some old grumpy man’s house. I stand up and stretch, feeling a crick in my neck and the soreness in my back. I was surprised an abandoned house had a bed still, let alone a mattress – no matter how hard. I felt like falling back to the ground though, living the rest of my existence there. It had to be better than feeling each and every ache that my body currently held. The supernatural world caught me off guard, but I can successfully learn to navigate through it, especially with Sydero’s help. The circumstances that led to this aren’t okay, but I can do this. I felt like falling back to the ground though, living the rest of my existence there. It had to be better than feeling each and every ache that my body currently held. [[Continue->A1_1]]Most of me wished that it was all some crappy dream. Maybe I watched a horror movie, and that’s where it all came from. Maybe bits of it was valid, but the majority was fabricated by my own mind. But here I was, living this crap. I’d pinch myself if I didn’t already know I was awake. I literally just fell out of a bed, I was awake. I stand up and stretch, feeling a crick in my neck and the soreness in my back. [[Continue->A1_1]]I leave the room in search of Sydero, finding her standing before a lone end table in the middle of the room. She looks comfortable, as if we weren’t both standing in a dilapidated house. I had on the same clothes that I wore yesterday, but here she was wearing a tank top, some loose cargo pants, and sandals. To top it all off, a large mug rests in her hands, and of course, a vulgar phrase is printed on it. “Morning,” I mumble, and her grunt is the only indication I receive that tells me she heard me. “I saw your bag, and there’s no way you fit all of that in there.” “Well, duh,” she snorts, yawning immediately after, “I have stuff upstairs.” I cock my head to the side, glancing at the rickety staircase. The same kind of staircase that you would find in an extravagant adventure story, the one the hero and less than wise sidekick had to cross over. She catches my look and sighs, gulping down the rest of whatever was in her mug. “This is one of my safehouses. What, you think I just put in a random address?” “I did, actually. Why abandoned houses? And if you’re going to choose abandoned houses, then why not at least make them more ... presentable?” “Does it look like I’m the type to have company? The more rundown they look, the better. I don’t need water or electricity, just a roof.” “And mice?” I say this as I glare at one that stares back at me. Apparently, I was the intruder here. “You get used to them,” she reassures. [["I hope not."]] [["We can change that."]] [["Great. Fun."]]“I’d rather not get used to these things. They’re not as cute when they’re sitting in front of your face,” I state, never thinking I would have such an experience. “Not all of them have mice. Some have roaches, others have –” “Stop talking. Just stop.” <<if $candychipssoda>>\ Before I can say the next thing on my mind, my stomach growls, "so, do you have anything to eat? I'm starving." "You ate on the way here." "Whoa, eating some candy and soda doesn't amount up to anything. Especially since you snuck some of my chips, the bag wasn't that big to begin with." "It was still something," she points out, believing her words to actually be true. "It was a snack to an otherwise stressful day." She shrugs her shoulders and takes a sip of her drink. "That depends on your perspective. Adopt a healthier and more optimistic one." She sneers as I scowl at her. <</if>>\ “What are we doing today?” I question, leaning up against the wall, making sure it was stable and didn't hold cobwebs. “You’re going to stay out of my way. One positive to the room I had slept in and my dreams, she wasn’t in them. But the truth remains, the two of us had just met, and it wasn’t under the best circumstances. I was willing to give her a chance if she was willing to provide me one as well. I leave her to check on my phone that was charging near my things, thankfully I had a portable charger with me. But the dilemma of where I would be able to recharge the charger would soon become an issue. It was just one thing on a long list of things that I needed to figure out now. Another, how I would get ahold of my things. I had a few of them now, but I would definitely need the rest, more clothes and shoes. <<if $uncledead>>\ I think about all the things I want to grab as I nonchalantly go through my phone, scanning the long list of missed calls and an alarming number of texts. A good percentage of them were from Chris. <<else>>\ I think about all the things I want to grab as I nonchalantly go through my phone, scanning the long list of missed calls. I notice a few texts sent from my uncle, asking for updates and complaining about the hotel staff. <</if>>\ I feel the weight of someone’s eyes on me, glancing up to see Sydero watching me. Our eyes meet, her amber one's against my $eyes ones. I wonder if she ever paused her thoughts to remark upon them, much like how I did upon hers. Did she see an intensity or a softness within mine? Did she see anything besides someone in over their head? Her eyes briefly flash to my phone before re-meeting mine, her brow raises as if questioning. “Let me guess, you’re going to tell me how stupid it is to reply.” “Close. I was going to say you’re stupid for even having your phone on. They will track you if need be.” [[Continue->A1_2]]After everything that has happened, I only wanted to either deal with it alone or to have someone who could console me when I needed it. I wasn’t one to judge before getting to know someone, even someone like her. Sure, she had a smart mouth and an unemotional, uncaring response to everything, but there could be a reason for that. They will track you if need be.” [[Continue->A1_2]]“I’m still not totally understanding why I have a target on my back when I’m not the threat.” She doesn’t say anything for a moment, completely immersed with the text in front of her. Instead of turning the page, she closes the book, stiffening as she looks over at me. “You’re affiliated with me, as soon as we got in that car together, you became a target. They probably think you know more than you’re letting on. They’ve killed for far less.” I continue to question her, but she ignores each question that I ask. “How about this, you go into town and grab what you need and what’s on this list for me.” She waves the list in her hands for me to see before writing more things down. “And what are you going to do?” “Start crafting these spells. I work better when I’m not surrounded by,” she pauses, her eyes flicker over to me, “yea.” I raise a brow at her choice in words, obviously evading wherever her thoughts were going. But it was for the best, whatever she was going to say would only lead to us arguing. “What kind of spells?” “Spells.” [["If we're going to be a team, I need honesty."]] [["So you want to be a smartass to the one picking things up?"]] [["I can play this game too."]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero -=3>> <<set $optimistic +=3>> <<endnobr>> "Look, Sydero," I begin, choosing my words carefully, "if we're going to be a team, then I need honesty. Something you're not giving me any of." “You know, you’re right. I need the items on that list for hexes that concern us, better?” “That’s literally the same thing you just said. Like, there was no difference besides the word which held the same connotation.” She turns her back to me and makes her way to the stairs, shooing me away. I lean on the doorframe and whistle out to her. Once she turns around, I dangle my keys confidently. Her smirk disappears once she realizes that I won this battle. “It’s cute that you don’t think I can get them from you. May I remind you that I’m a witch.” “You wouldn’t,” I say, but I already know the answer. She raises an eyebrow, as if that was an invitation for her to try. “Okay, maybe you would, but there’s no need for that. You’re making a big deal over something petty.” She sighs and nods in agreement, “a tracking spell and a cleansing one, the cleansing one is for you.” <<if $nerve >= 20>>\ “Was that so hard?” I tease. “I feel like I’m going to throw up. Is that all? Can you go now?” she questions, placing the money for her items in my hand. I snort, getting directions to the nearby town before leaving. <<else>>\ “Was that so hard?” I tease, my smirk disappearing as I look towards the door, “this is safe, right? Like, I won’t be tracked down immediately, will I?” “You should be fine if you go straight there and back and leave your phone out of it. Are you scared, Roe?” “Of course I’m scared,” I grumble, ending the conversation and getting directions to the nearby town before leaving. <</if>>\ [[Continue->A1_3]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero +=2>> <<set $stubborn -=3>> <<endnobr>> "So you want to be a smartass to the one picking things up?" I question in disbelief. “I can go pick them up myself,” she says as if she won this argument. “With what car?” I ask in mock confusion, dangling my car keys before her. Her smirk disappears once she realizes that I won this battle. “It’s cute that you don’t think I can get them from you. May I remind you that I’m a witch.” “You wouldn’t,” I say, but I already know the answer. Like I won’t be tracked down immediately, will I?” “You should be fine if you go straight there and back and leave your phone out of it. Are you scared, Roe?” “Of course I’m scared,” I grumble, ending the conversation and getting directions to the nearby town before leaving. <</if>>\ [[Continue->A1_3]]The store is a small grocery store that looks no bigger than an average restaurant. With one quick glance around the near-empty parking lot, I came to the conclusion that this was probably all the town had to show. A gas station, a store, and a diner that rivaled the size of the store. In a town like this, I would stand out. There would be no hiding that I’m a stranger, and in a town this small, lying wouldn’t be easy. As soon as I walk into the store, suspicious eyes fall on me, and whispers follow me as I walk towards my first aisle. I grab the list Sydero had given me and look it over. I don’t know what I expected to see, especially since she gave me the list knowing the store would be small, but I’m not sure I expected this. She needed salt and then different colored candles, further listing the exact colors that would aid her. [[Grab the things for Sydero.]] [[Do my own shopping.]]<<set $sydero +=2>> <<set $syderolist = true>> Before I go off to collect the things I need, I search for Sydero’s list of things. Salt was an easy object to acquire for obvious reasons, but the candles that she needed not as much. I grab as many candles as I can before leaving to check on my things. If I could somehow get into my apartment though, then most of my needs would be met. At the moment, there were so many things that I was feeling the loss of, my laptop for example. I think about all the things that I had left behind as I walk to the checkout counter. It is only when I see the clerk staring at me that I come out of my thoughts. I look around, curious if I had done something wrong, but I have not. She grabs one of the things and scans it, never breaking eye contact. A thought that hadn’t occurred to me until now arises. Who and who wasn’t supernatural creatures? Sydero stated that they hide in plain sight. So, anyone could actually be one. I eye the clerk suspiciously, and she eyes me back twice as untrustworthily. “I’ve never seen you around here,” she starts, “you visiting family?” “No, just passing through,” I answer. Anything else would bring up more questions. Judging by her look of disapproval, I was already unwelcomed as it is. As soon as she rings up my last item, I hurry out of the store, freezing at the three guys surrounding my car. They gaze through the windows, attempting to spot something of value probably, or perhaps even to learn who’s it is. “Can I help you?” I ask. They all straighten up, sizing me up immediately upon approach. They each wear worn-out jeans, outdoor boots, and plain t-shirts. They remind me of the type of guys who would rather be out fishing or hunting. The problem with that was that they were gazing at me as if I was the deer. “This is a mighty nice car.” Despite his diction, the man actually looked as if he could command respect. His smile reminds me of a devilish coyote, one who has found his prey wounded on the side of the road. He rounds my car until he appears in front of me, his grin widening even more as his finger makes a trail along the trunk. [["What do you want?"]] [["I was just leaving."]] [["Don't start nothing, won't be nothing."]]<<set $sydero -=5>> I ball up her list and toss it in the nearest trashcan, continuing on with my own list. I needed food, that was my main priority. Thankfully, the store had plenty of that. If I could somehow get into my apartment, then most of my needs would be met. At the moment, there were so many things that I was feeling the loss of, my laptop for example. I think about all the things that I had left behind as I walk to the checkout counter. It is only when I see the clerk staring at me that I come out of my thoughts. I look around, curious if I had done something wrong, but I have not. She grabs one of the things and scans it, never breaking eye contact. A thought that hadn’t occurred to me until now arises. Who and who wasn’t supernatural creatures? Sydero stated that they hide in plain sight. So, anyone could actually be one. I eye the clerk suspiciously, and she eyes me back twice as untrustworthily. “I’ve never seen you around here,” she starts, “you visiting family?” “No, just passing through,” I answer. Anything else would bring up more questions. Judging by her look of disapproval, I was already unwelcomed as it is. As soon as she rings up my last item, I hurry out of the store, freezing at the three guys surrounding my car. They gaze through the windows, attempting to spot something of value probably, or perhaps even to learn who’s it is. “Can I help you?” I ask. They all straighten up, sizing me up immediately upon approach. They each wear worn-out jeans, outdoor boots, and plain t-shirts. They remind me of the type of guys who would rather be out fishing or hunting. The problem with that was that they were gazing at me as if I was the deer. “This is a mighty nice car.” Despite his diction, the man actually looked as if he could command respect. His smile reminds me of a devilish coyote, one who has found his prey wounded on the side of the road. He rounds my car until he appears in front of me, his grin widening even more as his finger makes a trail along the trunk. [["What do you want?"]] [["I was just leaving."]] [["Don't start nothing, won't be nothing."]]I give them all a second glance, sizing them up for my own safety. “What do you want?” I ask. “We just wanna know where you got this pretty car,” one of them laughs, pushing the other roughly. His friend doesn’t seem to notice though, he was too busy glaring at me. Out of the corner of my eye, I see the quietest one approaching, his fingers drumming his pants leg. For a brief moment, my eyes go back to who I expect the leader to be. His eyes are currently on my car, longing residing there. When he looks back at me, he gives me another wolfish grin, and I swear I see canines. Were they supernatural? Werewolves perhaps? [[Continue->A1_4]]<<nobr>> <<set $pacifist -=3>> <<set $daring +=3>> <<endnobr>> <<if $combat >= 10>>\ I sit my grocery bags down, out of reach, so that whatever happens, it doesn’t destroy them. [[Continue->NGD8_1]]<<nobr>> <<set $stubborn +=2>> <<set $sydero -=2>> <<endnobr>> “I want the truth then,” I tell her and she pauses, thinking my words over. “No.” [[Deny her a ride.]] [[Give her a ride.]]I drive to work, not being able to get the woman from my mind the entire time. Who was she and what was she hiding? I’ve met some interesting characters in my time, but never one like her. That pure, intense look residing in her eyes was unlike anything I’ve ever seen. By the time I get to work, the thought of her begins to finally disappear from my mind. And as I work, she is shoved into storage along with any other stranger that I had exchanged words with. “Have fun,” I tell the group, letting them into the laser tag arena. I was becoming a pro at being able to speculate who would win these games. And from what I was gathering while I was addressing them, they were going to be nothing but a warmup for the other team. I suppose I should go in there and help them out, but I had already played enough games to gratify my need. I go sit down and retrieve my phone from my pocket, about to catch up on some videos when I hear a knock at the door. I freeze in my spot when I see my manager come in. “$name, some officers would like to speak with you.” I go over all the reasons they might want to see me, my only idea was that it had something to do with the woman. And yet, the two men that I find myself facing weren't familiar ones. <</if>>\ They say nothing, taking the opportunity to look me over as I do the same. His body language screams that he wishes to hurry this up so he can get on with more important matters. His partner, on the other hand, is shorter and can’t seem to get rid of his small yet friendly smile. <<if $knowher>>\ “Last night you found and brought a woman into the hospital. The hospital staff stated that you knew the woman, is this true?” the tallest one asks. Curiosity burns through me and for a split second, I wish to see her again to ask. <</if>>\ [[Continue->Outside the Alley]]<<link [img[images/divider.png]] >><</link>> ''Outside //The Alley// . . .'' A lone man takes a long puff from his cigarette, scrunching up his nose at the smell. He actually hated these things, yet the calming and numb feeling that they offered him was much too nice to pass up. He allows his eyes to settle on the building before him. The words ‘The Alley’ were painted blue and built in an annoyingly hard to read cursive font. The entire thing was an aggravating eye sore. The man produced a low growl due to his current predicament, not perking up until he spots two familiar figures walking towards him. “Well?” “It’s like you thought, the kid didn’t know much. I doubt there's any kind of ties between them.” The man nods at the report, flicking the cigarette to the ground. “What do we know?” <<if $addressknown>>\ “The kid gave us the address that she gave $him. Guess she needed a ride or something.” The man scrunches up his nose at the words, his eyes landing on the paper. He knew the address, heck they had just scoured the neighborhood that the house belonged to. Something was off. Why would she go back there? The only reason he could think of was that she had left something behind. Either way, it was a lead, and he would be a fool to waste it. “I’ll go check out the validity of the address, you two keep an eye on Roe.” “Why? I thought you said the kid was unimportant,” spoke the one who had barely spoken before. He was a man of a lot of words, but he wasn’t a fan of making a fool of himself. He was still trying to wrap his head around everything that was transpiring. “I said that the probability of $him not knowing anything is high, doesn’t mean we should rule out $him being an accomplice altogether.” Both officers nod as their boss turned on his heel and walked to one of the three waiting black SUV’s. <</if>>\ <<if $fakeaddress>>\ “The kid said that she requested to be dropped off at a nearby park. She probably was going to meet someone there.” The man scrunches up his nose at the words, stroking his beard as he thinks. Who could she possibly be meeting up with? Regardless of his doubts, it was a lead, and he would be a fool to throw it away. “I’ll go check out the validity of this, you two keep an eye on Roe.” “Why? I thought you said the kid was unimportant,” spoke the one who had barely spoken before. He was a man of a lot of words, but he wasn’t a fan of making a fool of himself. He was still trying to wrap his head around everything that was transpiring. “I said that the probability of $him not knowing anything is high, doesn’t mean we should rule out $him being an accomplice altogether.” Both officers nod as their boss turned on his heel and walked to one of the three waiting black SUV’s. <</if>>\ <<if $lieaddress>>\ “The kid said that $he has no idea where she went, she left as soon as they left the hospital.” With all the information, and experience, he had surrounding her, he could believe this more than anything else. True, she was a resourceful person, but she was a loner above all else. This was both a good and bad thing when it came to his job. It meant that detaining her should be easy, but to apprehend her they had to find her, and she was as slippery as they were determined. “I’ll go look for leads, you two keep an eye on Roe.” “Why? Don’t key a random person’s car, you never know who it could belong to. I suppose it was an idiotic thing to do in the first place, certainly not worth losing my job over. Now I would have to look for another job, one that paid half as well as this one. As I pack the things I kept in my locker, Chris pokes his head into the room. “So, it’s true, you got busted?” [["Darn cameras."]] [["Good riddance."]] [["Indeed, I have been let go."]] [["My smooth talk didn't help me out here."]] [["It's whatever."]] <<else>>\ After the two officers leave, my manager makes the decision to let me go early. It could be because she was worried about my own personal health or just didn’t want customers questioning, maybe even a mix of both. Either way, the choice didn’t affect my paycheck, so I didn’t complain. Instead, I quickly gather the few things I had sat down and leave before she has the chance to change her mind. As I head towards my car, I hear Chris call out for me. "So it's true, you're abandoning me?" he questions, wiping away an invisible tear. But what happened yesterday?” “I ended up having to help this woman that I found next to my job, I still don’t know what happened to her. [[Continue->NGD8_3]]“What is it?” I finally ask, knowing the question would haunt him for the rest of the week if he didn’t ask. He doesn’t look the least bit shocked by my question, even he knew that he did the act involuntarily. “You saw the therapist the other day, didn’t you?” I nod, realizing why he was nervous to ask. Most times he tried to stay out of it, even sometimes arguing that he didn’t believe I needed one anymore. He feared that talking about it would keep the wound open, never allowing it to close and heal properly. “And? Any episodes? Is everything still okay?” I keep any emotion from my face, but I can’t help but think about the creature that rested in my dreams. [["No, I'm still fine."]] [["No episodes but I'm worried."]] [["Yesterday ... I thought I saw one."]]He lets out a relieved sigh and smiles. We sit in silence for a couple minutes before he pats his legs. “I’m sure you’re hungry, I’ll go make your favorite and, if you want, you can spend the night.” I thank him and take him up on the offer, especially since it was late and after the memory of that thing, I didn’t wish to step out into the darkness. We eat and talk about random things like tv shows and what’s happening with the news. After cleaning up the kitchen and saying goodnight, I go to my old untouched room, and it doesn’t take me long to fall asleep. [[Continue->NGD8_4]]“Worried that you’ll have one soon?” I nod, and he nods in understanding but doesn’t offer me anything else. Despite all of this time together, my uncle is still unsure of how to deal with me. Sometimes I think this is because he doesn’t exactly know how he feels about what I think I saw. But he also doesn’t believe the therapists.
