After cleaning up the kitchen and saying goodnight, I go to my old untouched room, and it doesn’t take me long to fall asleep. [[Continue->NGD8_4]]“A ... creature?” he questions slowly, and I nod. I don’t know why I tell him, probably because I abhor the thought of keeping these things from him. Or maybe because actually saying it made me feel sane. Regardless of what my uncle believes, he has never judged me nor claimed that my dreams and sightings are false or ridiculous. He definitely doesn’t try to explain them by saying trauma. He offers little besides a worried stare, and we sit in silence for a couple minutes before he pats his legs. “I’m sure you’re hungry, I’ll go make your favorite and, if you want, you can spend the night.” I thank him and take him up on the offer, especially since it was late and after the memory of that thing, I didn’t wish to step back out into the darkness. We eat and talk about random things like tv shows and what’s happening with the news. After cleaning up the kitchen and saying goodnight, I go to my old untouched room, and it doesn’t take me long to fall asleep. [[Continue->NGD8_4]]<<link [img[images/divider.png]] >><</link>> I appear on a foggy street, a lone streetlight flickering before deciding that it’ll work for the time being. Rows of decaying houses stand on both sides of the road, unmanicured lawns enjoying their freedom. The only sound is that of a distant dog, continually barking at some unseen force. I search for the dog, and even try to go in the direction I believe the barking originates from, but always end up back where I began. I walk down the street, feeling as if I was walking in place, but the houses shift. The feeling is surreal, even for a dream. Was it natural to know one is dreaming but not be able to control it? To be completely mystified and unaware of what was happening? I continue down the street when I see a lone figure standing in the middle of the road, her black wavy hair immediately catching my attention. This was definitely the woman from earlier. I continue to approach her still body, cautiously closing the distance between us. Once I'm close enough, she picks up her head, her eyes wide in terror. They don’t seem to be staring at me, but through me. She stays like this, and despite my attempts at getting her attention, she doesn’t move. Suddenly, her body is pointed directly at me, her fingers gripping my arms and squeezing. If this were real, then she would have punctured flesh, drawing blood. Her eyes are now bloodshot, staring past my physical body and at my soul. She opens her mouth to say something when suddenly her body jolts backward, falling to the street in a heap. A blood puddle forms around her, growing larger by the second. Again, the world is quiet, other than the distant barks of a dog. [[Continue->NGD8_5]]<<link [img[images/divider.png]] >><</link>> The next morning, I roll out of bed near noon. I make a hot breakfast, rubbing my temples as I inhale the scent of french toast repeatedly. Despite the delightful aroma, it does little to rid my mind of last night’s dream. It was just a dream, right? Of little importance. Despite these words, I still find myself rubbing the area that the woman had grabbed hold of, it all felt so real and still did. Could it be a message, something actually meaningful? I sip my apple juice, desperately trying to forget the dream but finding it impossible. This was going to haunt me for the rest of the day, unless ... <<if $ride is true or $moneypromise is true>>\ <<nobr>> <<set $familiarstreets = true>> <<endnobr>> <</if>>\ [[Go see if the woman is okay.]] [[Drive directly home.]]<<nobr>> <<set $daring +=3>> <<set $stubborn +=5>> <<endnobr>> My uncle had already left for work, so explaining where I was going wasn’t needed. I grab my keys and bring up the address that she had given me. For all I know, she wouldn’t even be there, she was probably long gone. But still, checking was harmless. I get into my car and head out. I turn a corner when I notice a car behind me, attempting to seem nonchalant but ultimately following me. Maybe it was just my nerves, it wasn’t like I wasn’t on edge already due to that dream, as well as thoughts concerning the shadow creature. I was having one heck of a week, I didn’t wish to add paranoia to the mix. I take a few random turns, pissing my GPS off as I do so. I take notice of the car that continues to trail me. I even go in a circle and through it all, there it is. If I ever complained about the un-excitement of my life, I take it all back now. [[Act Three->EP1-Act Three]] <<nobr>> <<set $daring -=3>> <<set $stubborn -=5>> <<set $incustody = true>> <<endnobr>> My uncle had already left for work, so there was no need to say our farewells. I grab my keys and head out, doing my best to push the thought of the woman and the dream out of my head. When I arrive at my apartment, I’m still thinking about the dream, despite my attempts. I absentmindedly play with my keys as I walk, accidentally running into someone. I begin to apologize when they grab me. I look up in shock, the officer from yesterday standing there. “You’re coming with us." [[Act Three->EP1-Act Three]]<<nobr>> <<set $noblood = false>> <<endnobr>> <<link [img[images/actthree.png]] >><</link>> <<if $incustody>>\ “Let go of me,” I shout, trying to push the man away. His grip on my arm tightens, and he leans in towards my ear. <<if $darkburns is true or $darktruth is true>>\ “You want another permanent scar to haunt you for the rest of your life? If not, then you’ll behave.” I narrow my eyes, hoping to come off as intimidating but knowing by his smirk that I was failing. I grumble and relax partially, allowing him to pull me after him. He walks me to my car, forcing me to hand over the keys, before pushing me into the passenger's seat. Perhaps it was a petty and unimportant thing to think of at the moment, but no one has ever driven my baby but me. Seeing him get into the driver’s seat causes a ripple of anger to travel through me. Though I’m not able to explore it much, as the cop's partner joins us. <<else>>\ “You want a permanent scar to haunt you for the rest of your life? If not, then you’ll behave.” I narrow my eyes, hoping to come off as intimidating but knowing by his smirk that I was failing. I grumble and relax partially, allowing him to pull me after him. He walks me to my car, forcing me to hand over the keys, before pushing me into the passenger's seat. Perhaps it was a petty and unimportant thing to think of at the moment, but no one has ever driven my baby but me. Seeing him get into the driver’s seat causes a ripple of anger to travel through me. Though I’m not able to explore it much, as the cop's partner joins us. <</if>>\ “Langston, you wanna move your ass or are you still sightseeing?” the man growls, motioning for him to come on. “You need to seriously learn how to live life Petri, you’re going to die early if not,” his partner replies. This was the 'always smiling' one. He was much shorter than his partner and starkly different. First off, his skin was peachy white and he had hair, even though it was short and receding in some places. He had warm grey eyes, and paired with his smile, seemed very inviting. I can easily see these two interrogating someone and playing good cop, bad cop. Langston gets into the seat behind me. The man, Petri I believe, mumbles something about how he already was, but most of his words are said far too low for me to hear. <<if $addressknown is true>>\ <<if $cmajor is "Criminal Justice">>\ “What do you want? I already gave you the address. And I damn well know this isn't protocol, so either get out of my car or tell me what you want before I report both of you.” “Well, aren't you scary,” Petri chuckles darkly, “the boss came up with this idea. Last time we sent folks over there she killed them, so now you’re going to be our bargaining chip.” <<else>> “What do you want? I already gave you the address. Is this even protocol? Can you do this?” “Shut up,” Petri growls, “the boss came up with this idea. Last time we sent folks over there she killed them, so now you’re going to be our bargaining chip.” <</if>>\ <<else>>\ “What do you want? I already told you what I know.” “Shut up,” Petri growls, “the boss came up with this idea. Last time we sent folks over there she killed them, so now you’re going to be our bargaining chip.” <</if>>\ [["No thanks."->NGD9]] [["She barely even knows me."->NGD9]] [["I cooperated, this is no longer my problem."->NGD9]] [["I'm calling the cops."]] <<else>>\ The fear that I’m feeling is unlike anything I’ve ever felt before, though this was more so a good thing than bad. I was used to fear that struck me mercilessly and which would leave me paralyzed. Fear that caused me to question if death would be a better substitute. This fear, it was more of a nervousness. At best, it created a chill that rushes through my body. I look in the rearview mirror, the truck was now trailing behind me by two cars. I ponder my next move. [[Go into a nearby gas station.]] [[Lose them in traffic.]] <</if>>\<<if $incustody>>\ <<if $lieaddress>>\ “What? I already told you that I don’t know where she is.” “Still singing that song,” Langston questions, sighing and leaning on the car door, “we know what you said. But the boss doesn’t believe you.” “Do you have a warrant?” Langston raises an eyebrow. “I didn’t think so. If you would excuse me.” <</if>>\ <<if $fakeaddress>>\ “What? I already told you the address. Is this even protocol? Can you do this?” “Still singing that song,” Langston questions, sighing and leaning on the car door, “we know you lied, there's no trace of her ever being at the park.” “How would you even know -” <</if>>\ “Enough!” Petri shouts. His hand shoots out and clasps around my neck, squeezing tight enough for me to see the need to fight back, but Langston reaches around the seat and quickly subdues my arms. “Let me tell you how this is going to work, cos I’m low on patience. We’re going to drive to the address, and you’re going to act like you’re running away from us.” “No need to act,” Langston chuckles softly. “Once she comes to rescue you, we’ll have her.” “And what will you do with me?” “Depends on your acting skills.” He produces a growl so animalistic that I begin to believe the man was raised by dogs. He releases me, and I take several deep breaths, relishing the feeling of air entering my lungs once again. “So. You gonna cooperate?” <<nobr>> <<set $nerve -10>> <<endnobr>> [["Yes."]] [["I don't really have a choice."]] [["No way."]] [[Stay silent.]] <<else>>\ <<if $familiarstreets>>\ Thirty minutes later and I find myself driving down a familiar neighborhood. It looks exactly how it did the other day, I’m not sure why I would’ve believed it to look any different. With my paranoia as high as it is, I decide to park the car three houses down from the property I remember dropping the woman off at. I place a rock under the garage door, allowing me to hide the vehicle from view but not totally lock it up. <<else>>\ Thirty minutes later and I find myself driving down unfamiliar streets. The houses mock me as I get deeper, their age reflecting off of their cracked windows and rotting wood. With my paranoia as high as it is, I decide to park the car three houses down from the house that my GPS was giving me. I place a rock under the garage door, allowing me to hide the car from view but not totally lock it up. <</if>>\ As I back away, I believe I see a shadow flash out of the corner of my eye, but after inspection, find nothing there. “You’re in a creepy, abandoned neighborhood, you’ve just been chased by a truck, and you’re visiting a complete stranger that has the cops looking for her,” I start to remind myself as I go, “you’re allowed to be paranoid.” I take a few reassuring breaths but find that the effort is useless. The vibe I was getting was different than what I had been expecting. I felt more depressed than frightened, perhaps due to the sun's positioning in the sky, giving me a clear and beautiful view of everything. The idea that these houses, this neighborhood, was once alive with energy, now void of it all. It was also interesting to imagine how the neighborhood might’ve looked in its prime, how neighbors treated one another. I smile at the thought of children riding their bikes up and down the streets, dogs barking, and the joyful yet annoying sound of an ice-cream truck. I re-open my eyes, whatever the past held, the present has long forgotten. Unmanicured lawns and yards filled with an assortment of trash, all leading up to vandalized houses. But I wasn’t here to explore a street long overlooked by others. I turn, and my eyes fall on the house, 243 Melbrook Road. I approach the door cautiously, against my better judgment I knock. For all I know she could be gone, or someone else could be here. I jiggle the knob and find the door unlocked, entering and finding myself standing in a small foyer. Debris litters the floor, and a tall lamp with holes in its shade stands to the side. A small table with three legs rests perched up against the wall, but that is all that pulls my attention. I walk further into the house. A set of stairs leading up to the second floor sits beside an open arch that I presume leads to the kitchen. The room I’m standing in seems to be the living room, the furnishing that was left behind had all been pushed to the side so that a collection of symbols could be made there. In the middle of one symbol rests a bowl, an assortment of objects resting inside. [[Shout.]] [[Investigate the symbols.]] [[Look through the bowl.]] <</if>>\“We are the cops kid,” the man behind me states, Langston, says. “Fake!” “Nope, real. Dirty maybe, but real.” [[Continue->NGD9]]<<nobr>> <<set $daring -=2>> <<endnobr>> I need to act like I wasn’t totally freaking out at the moment. The only way I could think of keeping that lie up was by finding a decently crowded gas station and going inside. It takes a few gas stations, but finally see one with only one open parking spot. I park off to the side and get out, looking at the truck out of the corner of my eye. They park in one of the spaces next to the gas pump, but no one gets out. The windows are far too tinted for me to even hope to make out a face. Thankfully, a handful of customers are milling about. I inattentively browse a few of the shelves, attempting to figure out what my next move will be. Each idea that springs into my head is immediately put down by logic. Frustration racks my features as I gaze outside at the truck. Another car has pulled in, waiting patiently behind them since all the other pumps are full of cars. [[Get something while here.]] [[Exit the store.]]<<nobr>> <<set $daring +=2>> <<endnobr>> I increase my speed and think about all of the most crowded streets in the area. Thankfully, it was still early enough in the morning that others were still attempting to get to work. It takes two traffic lights and many angry drivers for the truck to get stuck in traffic. I take a few more unnecessary turns, just to be sure, before using the GPS to go to the address. [[Continue->NGD9]] <<nobr>> <<set $candychipssoda = true>> <<endnobr>> I let my eyes roam over the selection and decide to go with my favorite cheap candy, some chips, and a soda. “Will this be all for you?” the clerk asks me, and I nod, but most of my attention is still on the truck. The car behind them has blown his horn two times already. “Thanks,” I say and grab the food and drink. Once I get outside, the person in the car has had enough. They march to the truck’s window and bang on it, cussing them out. This was my chance. I pick up my pace and head to my car, hoping that luck was on my side. As I start my car, I see the truck attempting to pull out but forced to sit still due to a vehicle backing out of a space. I laugh to myself as I quickly pull out and drive towards a nearby neighborhood, randomly turning whenever I can. By the time I get anywhere near the address, I see no sign of the black truck. [[Continue->NGD9]] <<nobr>> <<set $daring -=3>> <<endnobr>> I go over to some of the symbols. I wasn’t an expert on the topic, but it didn’t look like demonic symbols. I knew enough to know what reversed pentagrams meant and looked like. The symbols remind me more of Native American origin, as well as witchcraft. But I can’t put a name to any of them. “What is this?” I ask aloud, picking up a small white and brown stick. “Are you hard of hearing?” a familiar snarky voice questions. I look up to see the woman leaning on the rail of the staircase, staring down at me. “What part of //forget// did you not understand?” “What is this?” I ask again. I dust some of the stick off, finding that its exact color was mostly a light grey. “That would be a two-month-old baby bone.” Her words immediately cause me to drop it, backing away from the bowl in fear. “What is this? [[Continue->NGD9_1]]<<if $incustody>> Thirty minutes later, I park the car in front of our destination, cutting the engine. I wipe sweat from my brow, not even knowing that so much had accumulated. “Now go in there and act like you’re being chased after,” Petri tells me, his eyes on the house as well. “This should be easy, it’s not really an act at all,” Langston chuckles. “Is that all I need to do?” “Yep. Just get her to come outside.” Petri takes his phone out of his pocket, motioning for me to go. I open the door when Petri grips my arm roughly. “Do anything that I don’t like, like trying to warn her, and I’ll rip you to shreds.” “Believe him,” Langston speaks up, “he has supernatural hearing and senses in general.” They were continuing on this supernatural creature trip then. I involuntarily swallow the lump in my throat and nod. Petri releases me but leaves a light bruise in his wake. I start walking, glancing back at the car before realizing that it wasn’t a smart move. I need to act like I was here alone, probably act frantic and desperate. I nod at my own plan, picking up my pace and then pounding on the door. “Please, help me! They’re after me now!” I scream at the door. “I know you can help me, just ... please. I don’t wanna die!” Was I laying it on a bit too much? Should I try to act composed or continue like this? I bang on the door a second time, even trying the handle when it suddenly jerks open. I stand at the threshold of the house, hardly making out the figure of the woman that I had met the other day. She stands at the side of the door, residing purely in the shadows. The only reason I can make out her facial details is because of the sunlight that was being allowed to stream in. “You’re not a clever one, are you? So, what’s this about you needing help?” “Men are after me,” I tell her, motioning to my roughed-up appearance. “They wouldn’t be if you had just done what I said. Remember I did say forget me.” [[Try to warn her.]] [[Continue trying to get her out in the open.]] [[Just ... plead.]] <<else>> “I still see no point in telling a complete stranger my reason for doing anything,” she finally tells me. “Would you not be curious if you walked in on me doing this?” I point to the symbols. She shrugs nonchalantly, “I would’ve never come back to find you.” “Then there’s that whole 'black truck following me' ordeal,” I continue to say, still believing it was pure luck that I lost them. “Wait, black truck? Did you see who was inside?” “No, everything was tinted.” “And you led them here?” she asks and walks to the window, looking out of it. For the first time since I’ve met her, she seems scared. “No. I lost them and parked my car two houses down.” If she hears me, I can’t tell. She leaves my side and goes into what I had already guessed to be the kitchen. I follow after her, watching as she picks up a bookbag stowed away in the corner and then setting it on the counter. She begins to go through counters, and much to my surprise actually brings down some water and other non-perishable items. “What are you doing?” “I’m getting out of here.” “Wait, why?” “You know, you ask a lot of questions.” “And you haven’t answered any of them.” “What can I say, it’s a curse,” she chuckles sarcastically. Whether it was my intolerance for the moment, or just my total confusion of the situation, that smirk of hers was grating my nerves. It constantly reminds me that I know little and will continue to be left in the dark. She goes back to what she was doing, it is as if I had disappeared entirely from the house. Obviously, I wasn’t going to get anything from her. This was a waste of both gas and time. [[Leave ... now.]] [[Offer my help.]] [[Demand answers.]] <</if>><<nobr>> <<set $pacifist -=2>> <<set $nerve +=5>> <<set $serious +=2>> <<endnobr>> “Or I’m snapping pictures and taking it straight to the cops.” She cocks her head to the side, a large smirk appearing on her face. “Go ahead, I like playing games just as much as the next person, especially with the cops. Now, what are you doing here?” She takes a threatening step closer to me, and I suddenly feel claustrophobic. My eyes shoot to the drawings on the floor. It would be wise not to anger her when I hardly knew what was going on. She was now inches away from me, and I felt it impossible to break the eye contact that she had started. <<if $int is "women" or $int is "both">>\ [[Her stare made my knees buckle, heat racing to my cheeks.]] <</if>>\ <<if $int is "women" or $int is "both">>\ [[I met her stare with one of my own, smirking flirtatiously.]] <</if>>\ [[Her stare made me wary, perhaps I should’ve gone home.]] [[Her stare was intimidating, but I stand by my decision.]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero -=3>> <<endnobr>> “Ugh, curiosity killed that cat, you know,” she points out, looking quite bored at my reason. [[Continue->NGD9_1]] <<nobr>> <<set $SRomance +=1>> <<set $sydero +=2>> <<endnobr>> Her eyes suddenly widen, a mix of shock and interest appearing. I can feel the heat rolling off of our close proximity, our bodies waiting to see who would make the first move. She does, but it is not the one I wish her to make. She takes a step back, placing that neutral mask back on. [[Continue->NGD9_1]] <<nobr>> <<set $sydero -=2>> <<endnobr>> My eyes roam to the ground, again spotting one of those unknown symbols. I was becoming quite queasy about all the things that my mind chose to claim the marking was. This was stupid. Had I truly forgotten that the cops themselves were after her? What did I get myself into? [[Continue->NGD9_1]] Regardless of what the cops said, I thought differently. Even now, her glare wasn’t one I expect a killer to wear. I don’t know what I see, I was unfamiliar, but I know that she wasn’t going to hurt me, or at least she didn’t plan to. [[Continue->NGD9_1]]<<nobr>> <<set $daring +=2>> <<set $sydero +=3>> <<endnobr>> “I know, and you were right, and I’m stupid to think that they wouldn’t come after me,” I tell her and raise my eyebrows at her. She cocks her head to the side in curiosity, amusement evident in her features. I try everything I can think of as I continue to try and get her to come out. I wink, blink uncontrollably, and even try to mouth my warning. She laughs at me, shaking her head as she closes the door slowly. Right before it closes, I hear her whisper. “You can stop the act, I already know they’re out there.” I freeze, wondering if that’s why she never came into full view. “I have to give you props on trying to warn me though, that was quite ... shocking.” I bang on the door, jiggling the handle, hoping to keep up the act for those watching me. “So, does that mean you’ll help me?” I question, relieved that at least that line wouldn’t give away my true intentions, “otherwise I’m dead.” There is silence from her side, and I begin to worry that she won’t, that perhaps she’s going to leave me to my fate. “Sure.” The door suddenly opens up, and her arm shoots out, grabbing me as she pulls me in. As she does this, I hear shouting. Though there are multiple voices, I only make out Petri and Langston’s, both yelling at me. “$name Roe, come out now,” I hear Petri shout in rage. Whether or not I trust or even think I have a chance of escaping this madness, I’m for sure not going back out there. Suddenly the glass breaks, and the two of us instinctively duck as more shouting from outside is now audible. The woman leaves my side and messes with a bowl in the middle of what I perceive to be the living room. She quickly grabs a bag and then grabs my hand as she rushes from the house through the back door. “Wait, what happened?” We’re forced to slow down as we try to navigate the thickness of the plants and long grass. “Just know that we need to get to your car as fast as possible. When I say go, we’re going to sprint to the car, keep your eyes closed.” I’m about to ask why when the house explodes in a blinding light ... just like the one I saw at The Alley. Was ... was she responsible for those that day? I manage to close my eyes just as they begin to feel an atrocious burning sensation. Not quite sure how the woman does it, but she yanks me onwards, and before long we’re back in my car and driving off. I don’t look back, out of fear that the light is still there. I feel like I’ve poured every soap known to man straight in my eyes. After we get away, we switch, and she lets me drive. But being behind the wheel without being threatened does little to calm my nerves or soothe my racing heart. So many things had just occurred, and where I thought some of my questions would be answered, hundreds more seem to have replaced them. It gets so bad that I’m forced to pull over. Not only because of a headache but also due to the need for answers. [[Continue->NGD10]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero -=5>> <<set $daring -=2>> <<endnobr>> “Come on, please, they’re just over here.” I move from my position and run a few steps away, motioning for her to follow desperately. “Sure, let me get my bag really quick,” she says in a tone I’m not familiar with her using. Of course, I hardly know her, but her tone has me raising a cautionary brow. She sees my expression and busts out laughing, wiping away an invisible tear as she closes the door. “Wait, no please!” I shout, dashing back to the door and banging on it in desperation. “Drop the act, I already know what’s going on and whose watching. Cute act though.” “So that’s it? You’re just going to condemn me to death?” I question, not being able to stop the anger that seeps into my voice. But why exactly was I angry? Who was I even mad at? There is silence from her side, and I begin to worry that she won’t help me, that perhaps she’s going to leave me to my fate. “Maybe.” The door suddenly opens up, and her arm shoots out, grabbing me as she pulls me in. As she does this, I hear shouting. Though there are multiple voices, I only make out Petri and Langston’s, both yelling at me. “But maybe not.” “$name Roe, come out now,” I hear Petri shout in rage. Whether or not I trust or even think I have a chance of escaping this madness, I’m for sure not going back out there. Suddenly the glass breaks, and the two of us instinctively duck as more shouting from outside is now audible. The woman leaves my side and messes with a bowl in the middle of what I perceive to be the living room. She quickly grabs a bag and then grabs my hand as she rushes from the house through the back door. “Wait, what happened?” We’re forced to slow down as we try to navigate the thickness of the plants and long grass. “Just know that we need to get to your car as fast as possible. When I say go, we’re going to sprint to the car, keep your eyes closed.” I’m about to ask why when the house explodes in a blinding light ... just like the one I saw at The Alley. Was ... was she responsible for those that day? I manage to close my eyes just as they begin to feel an atrocious burning sensation. Not quite sure how the woman does it, but she yanks me onwards, and before long we’re back in my car and driving off. I don’t look back, out of fear that the light is still there. I feel like I’ve poured every soap known to man straight in my eyes. After we get away, we switch, and she lets me drive. But being behind the wheel without being threatened does little to calm my nerves or soothe my racing heart. So many things had just occurred, and where I thought some of my questions would be answered, hundreds more seem to have replaced it. It gets so bad that I’m forced to pull over. Not only because of a headache but also due to the need for answers. [[Continue->NGD10]]<<nobr>> <<set $nerve -=3>> <<endnobr>> “Please, just help me. I’m sorry, okay?” I practically scream, realizing that I wasn’t really acting anymore. If this woman could help me, whether by being caught or by actually helping me out, then so be it. She closes the door slowly, laughing as she does. Right before it closes, I hear her whisper. “Continue the act, I know they’re out there.” I freeze, wondering if that’s why she never came out from the shadows, she’s known what was going on this entire time. “I would say your acting is great, but your appearance says otherwise.” “So, does that mean you’ll help me?” I question, stuttering as I ask the question, “otherwise I’m dead.” There is silence from her side, and I begin to worry that she won’t help me, that perhaps she’s going to leave me to my fate. “Sure.” The door suddenly opens up, and her arm shoots out, grabbing me as she pulls me in. As she does this, I hear shouting. Though there are multiple voices, I only make out Petri and Langston’s, both yelling at me. “$name Roe, come out now,” I hear Petri shout in rage. Whether or not I trust or even think I have a chance of escaping this madness, I’m for sure not going back out there. Suddenly the glass breaks, and the two of us instinctively duck as more shouting from outside is now audible. The woman leaves my side and messes with a bowl in the middle of what I perceive to be the living room. She quickly grabs a bag and then grabs my hand as she rushes from the house through the back door. “Wait, what happened?” We’re forced to slow down as we try to navigate the thickness of the plants and long grass. “Just know that we need to get to your car as fast as possible. When I say go, we’re going to sprint to the car, keep your eyes closed.” I’m about to ask why when the house explodes in a blinding light ... just like the one I saw at The Alley. Was ... was she responsible for those that day? I manage to close my eyes just as they begin to feel an atrocious burning sensation. Not quite sure how the woman does it, but she yanks me onwards, and before long we’re back in my car and driving off. I don’t look back, out of fear that the light is still there. I feel like I’ve poured every soap known to man straight in my eyes. After we get away, we switch, and she lets me drive. But being behind the wheel without being threatened does little to calm my nerves or soothe my racing heart. So many things had just occurred, and where I thought some of my questions would be answered, hundreds more seem to have replaced it. It gets so bad that I’m forced to pull over. Not only because of a headache but also due to the need for answers. [[Continue->NGD10]]“What are you doing?” she questions in a bored tone. We both knew what I was doing, but I suppose asking the question was her way of breaking the overmounting tension in the car. “I’m not going anywhere till I get some answers.” “Fine. I’ll hitchhike,” she chuckles triumphantly, and I lock the door. She unlocks it, but I again lock it back. We go back and forth with this petty game, seeing which one of us would give up first. Perhaps any other day I would, the stress and irritation beating out my curiosity. But this was pure madness, I could play this game for the next week and not be tired. She shouts in frustration and leans back in the seat. “Let me rephrase, //you’re// not going anywhere till I get some answers. Like who are those guys and what do they want? And what happened back there? And you never told me about what happened to you in the alleyway, or –” “Take a breather, would you,” she scowls, “fine. You want answers, and I have them. But let’s start with the basics, you need to understand that monsters are real, supernatural creatures – all real. Every little story you’ve ever heard about, every creepy thing, it’s real ... except for the boogie man. That’s a legend that backfired on parents trying to get their children to stop stuffing crap underneath their beds.” “And you expect me to believe that?” “I really don’t care what you believe. But why would I sit here and lie to you, about that anyway? There’s no point. It'd be simpler, not to mention quicker, to just tell you I'm a double agent being hunted by the mafia.” “So, you’re telling me that vampires, werewolves, ghosts, faeries, they’re all real?” “There’s way more than that, but yea.” [[“So why don’t I ever hear about them?”->E1Q1]] [[“These supernatural creatures look like us, I mean regular humans?”->E1Q2]] [[“So what happened to you in the alleyway?”->E1Q3]] [[“And those folks trying to kill us at the house?”->E1Q4]] [[“And you’re . . .”->E1Q5]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero +=2>> <<set $daring -=2>> <<endnobr>> “Again, nice talk,” I say, remembering our talk from the hospital. She continues on, ignoring me. I leave the kitchen when I hear her quietly say, “do you hear that?” I stop, trying to figure out what she’s talking about, and that is when I hear the clear sound of a nearby car. “Yea, it sounds like a car.” My words catch up with me, what would a car be doing in an abandoned neighborhood? We stand frozen as the sounds of more cars join in. We both race to the nearest window at the same time, gazing out of it in curiosity. Three black cars now appear outside, a group of people in all black standing in front of them, their eyes on the house. “Shit,” she growls, “thanks for leading them here.” <<if $addressknown>>\ “There’s no proof I even led them here,” I remind her, mentioning that my car is three houses down and the garage I had parked in is down. “They probably just came cos I told the cops your location.” The woman bites the inside of her cheek and clenches her eyes closed. She takes numerous breaths in before pushing past me roughly. Of course, her knowing that I gave her location away wasn’t going to be something she would be happy about. <<else>>\ “There’s no proof I even led them here,” I remind her, mentioning that my car is three houses down and the garage I had parked in is down. She taps her foot repeatedly against the floor, biting the inside of her cheek as she focuses on one splatter of dirt on the torn curtains. Suddenly she brushes past me, heading back into the previous room. <</if>>\ I watch her go before looking back out the window, noticing two recognizable officers. They were the same cops that had questioned me, never in a million years would I forget their faces, especially the tall dark-skinned bald one. “I recognize two of them,” I tell her, and she looks up at me. “Is that supposed to make me feel better?” <<if $addressknown>>\ “No,” I say and walk over to her. She erases a few of the symbols and scribbles down new ones, these I don’t recognize either. <<else>>\ “No,” I begin, walking over to her. She erases a few of the symbols and scribbles down new ones, these I don’t recognize either. “But how did they find me. They have no idea where you are.” <</if>>\ She ignores my questioning, settling back near the bowl. [[Joke about using a spell.]] [[Suggest that we make a run for it.]] [[Question. Her.]] [[Stay quiet.]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero -=2>> <<set $stubborn +=2>> <<endnobr>> “Listen, I can probably help you if you just tell me what’s up.” “You’re about one of the most annoying people I’ve ever met, you know –,” her eyes suddenly fly to the window, narrowing. “Do you hear that?” “Yea, it sounds like a car.” My words catch up with me, what would a car be doing in an abandoned neighborhood? But that could be my mind hallucinating, it was in a stage of utter befuddlement. “I can indeed.” Was she taking me seriously? Could she actually use a spell? <<if $addressknown>>\ “$name Roe come out now, we know you’re in there. We don’t want you but the woman. He’s a damn werewolf.” I look over at her, she’s still concentrating on whatever she was doing with the symbols and the bowl, her eyes frantically going from one symbol to the other as the gears turn in her mind. “You mean like they have a K9?” “Did I say K9? I said werewolf, as in full moon, howl at the moon, smelly little creatures that have an odd obsession with what? The moon.” She still doesn’t smirk or show any sign that she was cracking a joke. They exist?!"]] [[Stare.]]“Fine, don’t tell me,” I huff. “But I just did.” “You’re lying.” “You can go outside and see for yourself if you’d like.” I think about her words. She hadn’t lied to me yet. Instead, she just refused to tell me anything at all. But this, this was impossible. “Gimme your hand.” I hardly hear her, giving her my hand just because I make out valuable parts of the command. My mind is still trying to grasp her words. She didn’t say werewolves, she couldn’t. That would mean other supernatural creatures exist, right? No, this was a joke. They were fictional creatures, found only in fantasy and sci-fi stories. Mythical creatures created by another. I jerk my hand back in pain, finding a small but painful cut there. “What the hell?” I question, half of my attention on her and the other half on those outside barking orders about what I should do. “You're not afraid of a little blood, are you?” She asks, raising an amused brow. [["Actually I am."]] [[“When it's my blood then yes.”]] [["No, but that doesn't make you cutting me okay."]]<<nobr>> <<set $serious +=2>> <<endnobr>> “Nope, impossible.” I shake my head and cross my arms over my chest, refusing to believe such thing. She halts her frantic hands, sitting back on her knees and gazing at me with interest, “I haven’t lied to you yet. So why would I now?” “Cause you’re evil ... and tricky like that.” “I appreciate the compliment, but I can assure you I’m not lying. You can go outside and see for yourself if you’d like.” I think about her words. They did hold truth, she hadn’t lied to me. Instead, she just refused to tell me anything at all. But this, this was impossible. “Gimme your hand.” I hardly hear her, giving her my hand just because I make out valuable parts of the command. My mind is still trying to grasp her words. [["Actually I am."]] [[“When it's my blood then yes.”]] [["No, but that doesn't make you cutting me okay."]]<<nobr>> <<set $blood_fear = true>> <<endnobr>> “As a matter of fact, I am,” I tell her, hatred oozing off my words as I stare at the ground. The idea of seeing even the tiniest bit of blood on my hand could cause me to faint. Thinking about it wasn't doing me any favors either. “Alright. I need your blood to get us out of here. How about you look away and I do what needs to be done and wrap it with some thick gauze? You need to trust me right now.” “Trust you? That’s rich. You just cut me, and that’s only one thing amongst many others. You’re crazy.” “I did it for a damn reason,” she reassures me, and though I expect her words to be harsh and impatient, she says it in a soft and understanding tone. She reaches out for my hand again. [[Give her my hand.]] [[Refuse to.]] [[Question the purpose first.]]<<nobr>> <<set $blood_fear = true>> <<endnobr>> “When it's mine? She reaches out for my hand again. [[Give her my hand.]] [[Refuse to.]] [[Question the purpose first.]]“No but that doesn't make you cutting me okay.” Who raised this woman? “If you want to get out of here without dying then you have to trust me.” She reaches for my hand again, but I take a cautious step back, giving her a crazed look. “Trust you? That’s rich. You just cut me, and that’s only one thing amongst many others. You’re crazy.” “I did it for a damn reason,” she reassures me, and though I expect her words to be harsh and impatient, she says it in a soft and understanding tone. She reaches out for my hand again. [[Give her my hand.]] [[Refuse to.]] [[Question the purpose first.]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero +=2>> <<endnobr>> I don’t fight her or step back. She hovers it over the bowl and squeezes it, a few drops dripping down onto the items that she had chosen to leave in the bowl. <<if $darkburns>>\ Her gaze lingers on my arm, no doubt looking at the burn marks that appear as long gloves. I half expect her to ask how I received such a marking, but she doesn’t. <</if>>\ “There are some bandages in my bag, wrap the cut up.” Suddenly the glass breaks, the two of us instinctively ducking as the shouting from outside is now audible. She sets the bowl in the middle and quickly grabs her bag, grabbing my hand as she rushes from the house through the back door. “Wait what happened?” We’re forced to slow down as we try to navigate the thickness of the plants and long grass. “Just know that we need to get as far away as possible. Where’d you say you parked?” We switch, this time I lead her. I turn to ask her about what was supposed to happen when the house explodes in a blinding light ... just like the one I saw at The Alley. Was ... was she responsible for those that day? I’m forced to look away, due to the sheer intensity that the light gives off. It was like staring at the sun directly on the brightest and clearest day. I can only imagine what happens to those who are captured in the light. With help from her, we are able to escape, but I’m no less jumpy than I was before. So many things have just occurred, and where I thought some of my questions would be answered, hundreds more seem to have replaced it. It gets so bad that I’m forced to pull over. Not only because of a headache but also due to the need for answers. She said she would give them, and I was ready for the truth. [[Continue->NGD10]]<<nobr>> <<set $sydero -=5>> <<set $noblood = true>> <<endnobr>> “No thanks use your own. For all I know you’re a vampire, or I’m part of some sacrifice.” “Oh please, don’t flatter yourself.” She stands, her height dwarfing my own by a few inches. Just enough to where I had to angle my head to see all of her. “You’re damn lucky we’re both in the same situation, or I’d leave you to your own fate,” she growls and goes to grab the bowl. She then pushes past me and walks to the door. “You’re also lucky I know what I’m doing.” I hear her whisper words, in a language that was foreign to my ears. Suddenly the glass breaks, the two of us instinctively ducking as the shouting from outside is now audible. She sets the bowl in the middle and quickly grabs her bag, grabbing my hand as she rushes from the house through the back door. “Wait what happened?” We’re forced to slow down as we try to navigate the thickness of the plants and long grass. “Just know that we need to go, and we don’t have a lot of time. Thanks to someone not volunteering their blood.” “You’re trying to guilt trip me for my decision, and it won’t work.” “Just come on!” She yanks me just as the house explodes in a blinding light ... just like the one I saw at The Alley. Was ... was she responsible for those that day? I’m forced to look away, due to the intensity that the light gives off. It was like having someone shine a high-powered flashlight straight into your eyes. I can only imagine what happens to those who are captured in the light. With help from her, we are able to escape, but I’m no less jumpy than I was before. So many things have just occurred, and where I thought some of my questions would be answered, hundreds more seem to have replaced it. It gets so bad that I’m forced to pull over. Not only because of a headache but also due to the need for answers. She said she would give them, and I was ready for the truth. [[Continue->NGD10]]“Seeing that it’s my hand, I think I gain the right to ask why.” “We don’t have time for this.” I shrug and shove my hands into my pocket, raising a brow. She looks from me to the bowl and sighs, letting her head droop in defeat. “I need untainted, mortal blood.” “What does that make you?” “A witch. Look, we really don’t have time for this. I can explain all of this once we’re safe.” [[Give her my hand.]] [[Refuse to.]] “Do you think people just walk around telling others that they’re monsters or that they fight em or something? Did you not hear about what happened in Salem?” “Yea, but –.” “There’s no but. No one says crap about it because regular people can’t take it. I’m pretty sure you’re freaking out on the inside or doubting everything I say. People have enough crap on their plates than to have to worry about monsters too. So, we all let them walk around in their little imaginary world, letting them ignore the practical aspects.” [[“These supernatural creatures look like us, I mean regular humans?”->E1Q2]] [[“So what happened to you in the alleyway?”->E1Q3]] [[“And those folks trying to kill us at the house?”->E1Q4]] [[“And you’re . . .”->E1Q5]] [[Take it all in.->NGD10_1]]“I guess you can say that. We all have our ways of camouflaging ourselves. Witches and shapeshifters have an easier time, for obvious reasons. And if a group has no idea how to blend in, then they just hide.” [[“So why don’t I ever hear about them?”->E1Q1]] [[“So what happened to you in the alleyway?”->E1Q3]] [[“And those folks trying to kill us at the house?”->E1Q4]] [[“And you’re . . .”->E1Q5]] [[Take it all in.->NGD10_1]]“I got into a violent altercation with another being. Might’ve not told you everything, but I haven’t lied. I’m actually a very honest person.” [[“So why don’t I ever hear about them?”->E1Q1]] [[“These supernatural creatures look like us, I mean regular humans?”->E1Q2]] [[“So what happened to you in the alleyway?”->E1Q3]] [[“And you’re . . .”->E1Q5]] [[Take it all in.->NGD10_1]]“And in all of this, you’re a . . .” “A witch, yes.” “What were they again?” “A werewolf and a shapeshifter, also known as skin-walker or simply a shifter. I try to steady my breathing but end up hyperventilating instead. I have to focus on something, anything that would help clear my mind and calm my rapidly beating heart. Monsters are real. [[This actually makes me feel better.|NGD10_2]] [[Nope!|NGD10_2][$nerve -=2]] [[This is going to take a while.|NGD10_2]] [[Huh, kinda cool actually.|NGD10_2][$nerve +=2]] [[But aliens though.|NGD10_2]] [[My mind is officially blank.|NGD10_2]] [[Where's my hyperventilation bag?|NGD10_2][$nerve -=2]] [[I knew it.|NGD10_2][$nerve +=2]]I feel a heavy gaze on me and look to see her staring me down. She doesn’t flinch away from my gaze, which matches the curiosity of her own. “What?” I finally question, rubbing my head. I was in a car with a witch. I always thought witches just did spells and curses and charms, and even then, I didn’t think them very effective. But what if witches were what Salem painted them out to be? People with unique abilities? How dangerous was she, the girl with no name? Silence fills the car but doesn’t stay for long. She claps her hands and unlocks the car again, I lock it back. <<if $stubborn < 50>>\ “Wait,” I shout, and she does so without throwing an attitude, though irritation is a clear indication of one to come. “What do I do? I don’t know how to handle this.” “Obviously. Just keep your head down and don’t go anywhere for a few days.” <<else>>\ “Whoa,” I chuckle though it comes out sounding more like a nervous cough. She sighs and stops, turning to me with irritation painted across her face. “What do I do? I don’t know how to handle this.” “Obviously. Just keep your head down and don’t go anywhere for a few days. But I'm sure your stubborn ass will find a way to do the complete opposite of what I'm saying.” <</if>>\ “So, go home?” “No. That’s the opposite of what you do. Don’t go anywhere near your home. Don’t even go to a friend or families house.” I stare at her, hoping that she was exaggerating. “Why not? It’s not like they would have information on them.” <<if $cmajor is "Criminal Justice">>\ “Roe, these guys are still cops. Seeing that you're trying to get into that field, you should know what real authentic badges look like, and that dirty cops exist. They know who you are and if they care enough, they’ll ask around. Not to mention they probably have information about your family.” She pauses, gazing over at me with a critical eye. “Please tell me you don’t have any family nearby.” My hands stay locked on the steering wheel, my body shaking slightly as her words replay in my head. I don’t acknowledge her voice, my focus still on my last family member that was on the other side of town. <<else>>\ “Roe, these guys are still cops. This is suicidal, I’m telling you,” she murmurs. <<if $daring >= 50>>\ “Yes, thank you for the tenth time. Because I’m driving, I can’t necessarily see what she’s doing, though I keep glancing over in hopes of finding out. “You got three options.” “What are they?” “Continue on this road, take a nearby backroad, or completely forget roads and go off-road, there’s a trail that goes by your uncle’s address from what I see.” [[Go off-road.]] [[Stay on the current road.]] [[Take a backroad.]]<<nobr>> <<set $daring +=5>> <<endnobr>> “You might want to hold on,” I tell her and before she can even think of questioning me, I swing the car around. I suddenly feel like I’m in a video game, or at the arcade, recklessly driving to earn the bragging rights. The vehicle drifts dangerously close to a nearby pole, just barely avoiding it along with incoming traffic. I turn the steering wheel with the screeching tires before straightening back out. The turn is complete, and we’re still in one piece. I gaze over at the woman, smirking when I see her clutching on to the door, staring at me as if I had gone crazy. “We survived, didn’t we?” “I hate you.” I chuckle continuing to follow the GPS to my uncle’s house. I can only hope that I get there before anyone else. I run up the driveway to my uncle’s house, preparing to bang on the door when I find it already unlocked. My entire world freezes, as I push it further open, silence residing on the other side. I head inside, checking the living room and then the kitchen. Nothing was out of place, it was the same as I had left it. [[Everything was okay.]] [[Something was definitely wrong.]]<<nobr>> <<set $uncle to 1>> <<endnobr>> “If that’s your take away from me claiming death then okay.” “Mind checking all possible routes, maybe there’s a faster way.” She picks up my phone and begins fiddling with the navigation. “You got three options.” “What are they?” “Continue on this road, take a nearby backroad, or completely forget roads and go off-road, there’s a trail that goes by your uncle’s address from what I see.” [[Go off-road.]] [[Stay on the current road.]] [[Take a backroad.]]<<nobr>> <<set $uncle +=2>> <<set $uncledead = true>> <<set $optimistic -=3>> <<endnobr>> “What’s the point?” I ask, taking my foot off the gas and relaxing my grip on the steering wheel. I’m highly confused about your motives.” I don’t answer, picking up the phone and looking at my uncle’s number. “I’m literally trying to out beat supernatural creatures as if that’s actually possible.” She snorts in disgust, “ugh, if you’re going to go all gloomy and sentence people to death then at least be accurate. I sneer but don’t slow down, if anything I speed up. The biggest thing was the officers who loved to patrol the area. I take it, accelerating as we get further down the street. If this were a Hellcat or a Demon, then it would be faster.” If it was possible, her smirk widens. My uncle was okay, the house was okay, there was nothing to worry about. It was getting late, for all I know my uncle had just retired to his bed early. It wasn’t unheard of, and if his day was tough, then it was actually expected. There were no signs of forced entry, no signs of a struggle existing, and the house was silent. It would be okay. [[Continue->NGD10_3]] <<nobr>> <<set $optimistic -=5>> <<endnobr>> Despite everything being left the way I last remember it, I knew I couldn’t take my cues from that alone. I would have to check out the rest of the house, as well as confirm with my own eyes my uncle’s safety. My gut screams that something is off, and my eyes only wait for the curtains to come falling down to prove such thing. [[Continue->NGD10_3]] <<if $uncledead>>\ I make my way up the stairs, slowing down when I spot a red mark on one of the stairs. It could’ve been overlooked on a typical day, almost doing a perfect job of blending in with the cherry wood. But I was on guard for things like this. I blink a few times, rubbing my eyes, and mentally telling my heart to slow down its rapid beating. “Uncle?” I ask in a shaky voice, going further up the stairs. I see another print on the railing, followed by a trail of thick blood that was done oozing off the side. “Matheus?!” I scream, dashing up the rest of the stairs and charging to his bedroom door. I turn the knob, but the door refuses to budge, something on the other side blocking my entry. <<if $athleticism >= 10>>\ “Uncle Matheus?” I shout, bracing myself and counting to three. Once I hit three, I turn the knob, at the same time as slamming into the door with all of the force I can muster. The door opens up easily, and I stumble inside. <<else>>\ “Uncle Matheus?” I shout, bracing myself and counting to three. Once I hit three, I turn the knob, at the same time as slamming into the door with all of the force I can muster. The door budges, but I’m no closer than I was before. I repeat the process numerous of times, ignoring the pain that flees up my side. Finally, the door opens, and I stumble inside. <</if>>\ I scream in both surprise and horror at the sight. My uncle’s room was trashed, from the wall to the floor. Bloody handprints decorate the walls along with a few small and large divots. The room had been remodeled with the dresser on its side and blocking the closet, the mattress resting up against a wall, and broken glass scattered across the floor. Written on a wall were the words: You’re Next. Try as I might, I can’t fight where my eyes travel to next. Hanging from a ceiling fan hangs my uncle, his eyes wide open and lacerations rest all across his body. What was once flawed skin was now waxy and turning an unnatural purple hue. One clean tear in the stomach area caused for his entrails to dangle out, clinging to a dead body. Most of his lower body, and the floor, was painted red by his still fresh blood. Some specks still dripping off of his shoes, though the sound of them hitting the puddle was drowned out by my cries. “Uncle Matheus!” I hear someone scream, wondering if it was me, but I wasn’t sure. I don’t remember opening my mouth or screaming anything. I can’t even sense what I’m doing, if I was walking or standing or on the ground. [[Bring him down.]] [[Remain where I am.]] <<else>>\ I head towards the stairs when I hear a door close. I glance up to see my uncle appearing, bewildered to see me there. “Guess I didn’t lock the door. But I wasn’t expecting you, $name. What are you doing here?” “No time to explain. Grab that travel suitcase you always use and some essentials and come on.” “Why?” “Please, Uncle Matheus, I know this is completely weird and scary but just go get a suitcase and come on. We don’t have time.” He stares at me suspiciously before agreeing, turning and heading to his room. I stand in my spot for a few more seconds before walking back outside, heading towards the woman. She leans up against my car, her eyes scouring the neighborhood. There was enough light still out that if anyone suspicious were to show up, we would see them before they probably saw us. I sigh once I've made it to her side, leaning on the side of my car as well, “anything?” “No.” “Why do you say it like that’s a bad thing?” “I’m not used to things going according to plan. Any minute now they’ll show up and finish what they started.” [["How long have you been on the run?"]] [["Maybe your luck is changing."]] [["Not really an optimist, huh?"]] [["Anything to make you feel more comfortable?"]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $nerve +=5>> <<endnobr>> I stumble towards him, feeling my body shake uncontrollably but not knowing how to stop it. I absentmindedly begin to undo the rope, until it’s loose. I hear a thud and then another, my body collapsed on the ground right next to my uncle's. But my eyes stay on the wall in front of me, my body still trying to get its bearings back. I feel the presence of another behind me, and I glance up to see the woman looking around the room, her eyes landing on my uncle last. She examines him for a minute from her spot, before her eyes travel down and meet mine. With nothing but a blink, she turns on her heel and marches out of the room. “So, you just walk away?” I scream, finally finding my voice. I get to my feet and go after her, stopping her before she could travel down the stairs. “You catch on pretty quick when you want to.” “How heartless can you be? They did this, just because I helped you?” I ask in desperation. She takes a few steps down the stairs and turns to me. “I told you, forget. You brought this on yourself.” I clench my jaw, and through gritted teeth say, “so, I should’ve just let you suffer in that alleyway?” She continues walking down the stairs. I keep thinking that she’s going to stop and utter some nonsense statement or say something irrelevantly sarcastic, but no. She keeps going. Out the front door and out of my life. [[Continue->NGD10_4]]<<nobr>> <<set $nerve -=3>> <<endnobr>> I don’t move a muscle, not entirely sure I could even if I did choose to. I can only feel myself sobbing, my mind choosing now to replay pointless memories. I hear words being uttered but they’re incomprehensible, just a bunch of gibberish seeping out of my mouth. I hear a thud but still don't register my body collapsing as I stare on. I feel the presence of another behind me, and I glance up to see the woman looking around the room, her eyes landing on my uncle last. She examines him for a minute from her spot, before her eyes travel down and meet mine. With nothing but a blink, she turns on her heel and marches out of the room. “So, you just walk away?” I scream, finally finding my voice. I get to my feet and go after her, stopping her before she could travel down the stairs. “You catch on pretty quick when you want to.” “How heartless can you be? They did this, just because I helped you?” I ask in desperation. She takes a few steps down the stairs and turns to me. “I told you, forget. You brought this on yourself.” I clench my jaw, and through gritted teeth say, “so, I should’ve just let you suffer in that alleyway?” She continues walking down the stairs. I keep thinking that she’s going to stop and utter some nonsense statement or say something irrelevantly sarcastic, but no. She keeps going. Out the front door and out of my life. [[Continue->NGD10_4]]<<if $uncledead>> I stand frozen on the staircase, still staring at the door. How one good deed just changed my life, made me question everything I know. But it wasn’t just the past that haunts me, it was also the future. If what she said, and the message they left proved correct, they would be after me. And then there were the cops, I couldn’t just report this to them. What would I even tell the police? What if those that came were in on it too? I tremble and feel something crawl up my stomach, proving itself to be vomit. I hunch over, trying to catch my breath and get some semblance of sanity back. I can’t stay here. I have to get out of the city. And my best hope of surviving this was to get her help. [[I want revenge.]] [[I need her for survival.]] [[She was a witness, and I need her.]] [[She was all I had now.]] <<else>> In both hands are two suitcases, as well as a large duffle bag on his shoulders. “What did you tell him? To move out?” “Of course not,” I growl and approach him, “Uncle, what is this?” “It’s everything I need. You sounded urgent, so I packed urgently.” I hear her laugh and throw her a look. That sound coming from her, it was - odd. She doesn't look phased by the look and after clearing her throat, straightens up, “Come on, we need to go before they get here. I’m sure they know your car now.” I agree, and once we’re all piled in, I drive us away. “So, anyone going to tell me what’s going on?” my uncle asks, his eyes studying the woman in the passenger seat. [[Tell Uncle Matheus the truth.]] [[Lie to Uncle Matheus.]] [[Tell him what he needs to know.]] <</if>><<nobr>> <<set $motive = "revenge">> <<endnobr>> Those who did this to my uncle, they’ll do much more than pay. Every fiber within me knew what needed to be done, death would take me before I let them get away. The only way to do that was to get her help, she knew far more than I did, and she had abilities. I feel like I was now seeing the world for what it was, and it was a world that I wouldn’t get far in without her. It was a decision that I knew I had to make, a decision with little choice. If there were another way, then I would gladly take it. But what choice did I have? I would now be hunted, and the only way out was the way I was taking. Which was more of an in, than an out. I rush to the room I used to stay in and gather some of my things. I would have to somehow get access to my actual apartment to grab more, but that problem would be there for tomorrow me. I rush down the stairs, pausing when I see a picture of my uncle and me together. [[Take it.|NGD10_5][$unclepicture = true]] [[Leave it.|NGD10_5][$sympathy -=2]]<<nobr>> <<set $motive = "survival">> <<endnobr>> I wouldn’t make it. That was a fact that I knew and wasn’t too prideful to ignore. The first day of learning that supernatural beings exist, and I was suddenly on their hit list. It wasn’t just that, I haven’t even seen one in its true form yet. I watched television and read books like everyone else, but how did one truly kill a supernatural being? Was there any truth to what entertainment sources said? It was a decision that I knew I had to make, a decision with little choice. If there were another way, then I would gladly take it. But what choice did I have? I would now be hunted, and the only way out was the way I was taking. Which was more of an in, than an out. I rush to the room I used to stay in and gather some of my things. I would have to somehow get access to my actual apartment to grab more, but that problem would be there for tomorrow me. I rush down the stairs, pausing when I see a picture of my uncle and me together. [[Take it.|NGD10_5][$unclepicture = true]] [[Leave it.|NGD10_5][$sympathy -=2]]<<nobr>> <<set $motive = "justice">> <<endnobr>> Going to the police was a foolish notion. They would laugh at me and undoubtedly throw me in the psych ward, either that or put me on the list of potential suspects. I imagine myself in a court, listening as another tries to defend me against killing my own uncle. If I had her, I would at least have a witness. She could at least point the police to those responsible. It was a decision that I knew I had to make, a decision with little choice. If there were another way, then I would gladly take it. But what choice did I have? I would now be hunted, and the only way out was the way I was taking. Which was more of an in, than an out. There was Chris of course, but dragging him into this would do more damage than anything else. His reaction would be similar to mine if not worse, and he hadn’t heard what I heard, seen what I’ve seen. But her, she was a direct link, she knew what I was going through, and she knew about this world. She wouldn’t look at me like I was crazy. It was a decision that I knew I had to make, a decision with little choice. If there were another way, then I would gladly take it. But what choice did I have? [[Take it.|NGD10_5][$unclepicture = true]] [[Leave it.|NGD10_5][$sympathy -=2]]“Since I was born.” I snort at her exaggeration, but the look that she passes my way has me rethinking. [[Continue->NGD10_4]] <<nobr>> <<set $honesty +=3>> <<endnobr>> I tell him only what he needs to know to be safe and to avoid him asking the unnamed woman any questions. Of course, it does little to sate his curiosities, but his trust in me goes farther than I was led to believe. I go to a three-star hotel and help him check in. “$name, I’m worried about you, what will you do?” “I don’t know. I was thinking about that on the way over here. I think there’s only one thing I can do.” He seems to know what I’m thinking and nods, resting his hand on my shoulder, I can feel it shaking and see his lip quivering. “Please, be safe. I don’t know what else to say. I want to say don’t, but I don’t know. I just don’t know.” I nod in complete understanding, hugging him. “I’ll call whenever I’m situated.” We separate, and he hands the duffel bag to me. “I didn’t know what was going on, but I packed all of the clothes you leave at my place for your never timed right visits. I’m kinda happy I did it now.” I thank him and give him another hug, turning my back to him and walking back outside. [[Continue->NGD10_5]] <<nobr>> <<set $honesty +=5>> <<set $uncleknows = true>> <<endnobr>> At first, I wasn’t planning on telling him everything. But pieces didn’t make sense without others, and soon I’m telling him everything. No detail was left undiscussed, and a good portion of the ride is spent in silence. Him reflecting and asking brief questions, more towards my unnamed associate than to me. I go to a three-star hotel and help him check in. “Are you sure you’re going to be okay? I’m more than worried. I don’t exactly know what I am,” he trails off, his eyes wandering to his suitcase zipper. He plays with it, avoiding eye contact. “You don’t believe me?” “I don’t know what I believe. You wouldn’t do something so drastic if you were lying, and you have no reason to lie to me. Plus, that story, the details and how you told it ... it’s not that I don’t believe you but that I don’t want to. I woke up this morning thinking about what I was going to have for lunch. I’ll be going to sleep wondering if my boss is a vampire.” “It’ll explain a lot, huh,” I attempt to joke, and he chuckles, relaxing. “I’m worried about you though, what will you do?” “I don’t know. I was thinking about that on the way over here. I think there’s only one thing I can do.” He seems to know what I’m thinking and nods, resting his hand on my shoulder, I can feel it shaking and see his lip quivering. “Please, be safe. I don’t know what else to say. This isn’t my field ... at all. I want to say don’t, but I don’t know. I just don’t know.” I nod in complete understanding, hugging him. “I’ll call whenever I’m situated.” We separate, and he hands the duffel bag to me. “I didn’t know what was going on, but I packed all of the clothes you leave at my place for your never timed right visits. I’m kinda happy I did it now.” I thank him and give him another hug, turning my back to him and walking back outside. [[Continue->NGD10_5]]<<nobr>> <<set $honesty -=5>> <<endnobr>> I lie, hoping to persuade him into believing that I was redecorating part of the house as a surprise. I go to a three-star hotel and help him check in. “Are you sure you’re going to be okay? You seemed on edge earlier. Not to mention what you told me yesterday, and well,” he trails off, his eyes wandering to the woman who still had no name. “I’ll be fine ... I just need to figure out what I’m going to do.” “$name, talk to me,” he rests a hand on my shoulder and tries to meet my gaze. “I’m fine, Uncle, one of these days you’re going to stop worrying about me,” I say in a joking manner, but he doesn’t crack a smile. He instead hands me the duffel. “These are your clothes, I thought you might want them. I don’t know why.” I thank him and give him another hug, promising to call later on. With that, I turn my back to him and walking back outside. [[Continue->NGD10_5]]<<if $uncledead>>\ I place the duffel bag in the back seat of my car and get in, driving down the street in search of No Name. Remember what I said and you’ll be fine.” Without even a proper goodbye, she begins to trek away. “Wait, that’s it?” I shout after her, and she stops, turning to me with genuine confusion. “Yea. Your uncle’s safe and you’re still kicking. No death can be blamed on me, so I’m going to disappear. I have shit to handle.” “Do you do this a lot? [[Continue->NGD10_6]]<<nobr>> <<set $SyderoTheron = true>> <<endnobr>> <<if $uncledead>>\ “Where to then, Sydero?” “Your uncle’s house.” “Why?” “You’ll see.” I don’t question her, turning the car around and heading back to the place that holds memories both good and bad. The two of us sit quietly, looking at the house as if we were old friends, afraid to approach whoever resided inside. She finally speaks, “your uncle’s body. We need to get rid of it unless you want the police putting you at the top of their list for suspects of murder.” “Doesn’t getting rid of it make me seem even more likely?” “That’s why I think you should make it look like an accident. I have a spell that can work, but it requires a house fire.” “You seem too calm about all this; how many times have you done this?” “This exact thing? Not much. Make a kill look like an accident? Tons of times. The question is: do you want to do this, or shall I?” I look at the house that I grew up in. I imagine all the times where my uncle would play with me in his yard, the times we would have water balloon wars or snowball fights. The images disappear and are replaced by the look on his face as he died. All that remains are questions about how quick his death was and what was going through his mind during it. I understood why this needed to be done. I had to go off the grid. If the house stands and I disappeared with the body still inside, I was more than a suspect. Regardless of what was inside and whatever I said. Those after me, along with the police, would at least pause at this. It’ll buy us needed time. [[“I’ll help.”]] [[“You can do it.”]] <<else>>\ She taps the side of her cheek, murmuring some words to herself. The best that I can guess is that she’s weighing her options. At one point, her eyes meet mine and refuse to look away. She studies me with such intensity that I feel like I’m under a microscope. She walks back over to me, stopping once she gets to the other side of the car, “you join me, and your entire life is going to change, and you’re going to have to change with it.” “Done.” “Aren’t you in college, you’ll just throw that away?” “It's finals, and besides having to turn an essay in, I’m done. I could use a little break next fall anyway.” “You’re going to have people and things hunting you.” “Okay, too late.” “Everyone you know, you no longer know. Unless you want to see them dead.” I nod in understanding. “You say all of this now, but as soon as it happens, you’re going to be thinking differently.” “Let me worry about my existential crisis.” She takes a deep breath and cocks her head to the side, studying me once again. Finally, she offers me her hand, and I shake it. “Name’s Sydero.” Sydero, I test the name again and again, all without saying it. I nod and let go of her hand, and she takes a step back. She sets her bag in the back seat and then gets in. She grabs my phone and gives me the location to drive towards, and I do so. [[Continue->NGD11]] <</if>>\I watch as she almost trips over her own feet, turning to face me. “What’s your point?” “I come with you.” She looks ready to argue, but before she says anything, she stops herself.
