I nod, but I’m still not happy about the idea of just sitting here while Chris could be getting into who knows what. “What do we have and know?” Bradley questions and we list out all the things that could possibly help us out. Despite the new information that Bradley gave us, I still feel like we’re far from any kind of decent lead. Our best lead is running around Bladenboro, a place we don’t know, hoping to catch Chris, who was going through who knows what. “So, find Chris or find the beast?” Sydero asks. “Find Chris, we don’t need him running around looking like a madman,” Bradley tells us. “Where’s his current location now?” I ask. I hear Bradley typing before giving us the location ... the park. We hang up after Bradley promises to look deeper into the legend, as well as try and come up with guesses of what might be befalling Chris. We head towards the park. There were a few street lights on, but otherwise, it was dark and silent. <<if $hangover>>\ “Do you feel the need to just lay down on the grass and go to sleep?” I question Syd, running my hands through the grass ... how did I end up down here? “Shame, drunk Roe is pretty entertaining. I’m going to miss $him,” she chuckles, yanking me to my feet and dragging me towards the woods. “Speaking of drunk Roe, should I be going in there with you? I feel like I’ll get in the way.” “You’ll be surprised at what fear can do to a hangover.” <</if>>\ [[Continue->BB3]]“I don’t understand,” I start, “this has nothing to do with the beast. Just some random teen who decided to play hooky and happened to be scratched by a cat, whoopty doo.” “Oh, I forgot that I haven’t told you guys what I also found. I think I know what you’ve been after this entire time.” “Well?” I question. “There’s a legend around it that might either be true or not, but the locals call it the Bladenboro Beast.” Bradley gets quiet, probably wanting his words to sink in. “Not very creative if you ask me,” Sydero mumbles, “what else did you learn?” “Not much. Legend says that the beast is some large creature that feeds on animal hearts. A couple of years ago it was attacking and those that claim to have seen it always claim that it’s massive, walks on all fours, have blue eyes, and sharp fangs. Everyone thought that they killed it when the locals killed a cougar and the killing stopped, but no one was one-hundred percent sure.” [[“So, why did the killings stop?”]] [[“So, is it a werecat or not?”]]“Hmm, sounds like this young lady is just another crush of yours, you sly dog you,” I joke, but Bradley looks less than amused at my teasing. “No, I don’t know this girl,” he corrects. “Yea Roe, Bradley is a one lady at a time type of heartbreaker. He doesn’t move on to the next until he has secured another broken heart to his collection,” Syd jokes, causing Bradley to groan in frustration. “Seriously though, what does this have to do with our supernatural? It doesn’t sound related,” I point out. “Oh, I forgot that I haven’t told you guys what I also found. I think I know what you’ve been after this entire time.” “Well?” I question. “There’s a legend around it that might either be true or not, but the locals call it the Bladenboro Beast.” Bradley gets quiet, probably wanting his words to sink in. “Not very creative if you ask me,” Sydero mumbles, “what else did you learn?” “Not much. Legend says that the beast is some large creature that feeds on animal hearts. A couple of years ago it was attacking and those that claim to have seen it always claim that it’s massive, walks on all fours, have blue eyes, and sharp fangs. Everyone thought that they killed it when the locals killed a cougar and the killing stopped, but no one was one-hundred percent sure.” [[“So, why did the killings stop?”]] [[“So, is it a werecat or not?”]]We march to the outskirts of the familiar woods, stopping there. “Those are some pretty big woods, we might not be able to find him so easily,” Sydero starts, curling up her lips in disgust, “Bladenboro Beast, I hate local cryptids.” “Why?” “I know how to put a werewolf or vampire down, but local cryptids are always a special case. Your only source of information about them is local and you gotta hope there’s enough to go off of.” She grabs her unique blade and expertly tosses it a short distance into the air, admiring it, “luckily, most supernaturals die or at least are injured by silver.” I hear an owl in the distance, jumping into Syd as I tell myself to calm down. Woods and I didn’t have a good track record, and the last thing I wanted to do was go into them at night to find my crazed best friend and some local cryptid. “Chill, Roe, you can’t tell me you’re afraid of an owl.” “Of course not,” I huff. “You sure?” [[“I actually am kinda scared of birds.”]] <<if $doglike isnot true>>\ [[“No, I'm terrified of dogs.”]] <</if>>\ <<if $catlike isnot true>>\ [[“Birds I'm fine with, it's cats that make me scream.”]] <</if>>\ [[“I actually don’t like insects.”]] [[“Yes, now if that was a spider, it’s a different story.”]] [[“I’m terrified of snakes actually.”]]<<nobr>> <<set $a_fear = "birds">> <<endnobr>> “Well,” I say, hearing the owl again, “I actually am kinda scared of birds.” Syd whips around, giving me an incredulous look. “You’re kidding? So, a parrot comes, and you just shrivel up?” “Shut up,” I growl, “from a distance, I’m fine. But as soon as they come closer, I freak out.” My stomach churns at the thought of one coming super close, and I wave the thought and conversation away. Thankfully, Syd seems ready to start searching, entering the woods with me right behind her. <<if $cp>>\ [[Continue->BB3_1]] <<else>>\ [[Continue->BB4_1]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $a_fear = "dogs">> <<endnobr>> “No, I'm terrified of dogs though,” I tell her, straightening up. “Dogs? Seriously? I mean, I don’t like them, but you’re scared of those cute little faces?” I ignore her but she doesn’t let it go, “so, how did you deal with being around them earlier?” “I stiffen and ignore it the best way I can.” Thankfully, Syd doesn’t seem interested in learning any more, instead she seems ready to start searching, entering the woods with me right behind her. <<if $cp>>\ [[Continue->BB3_1]] <<else>>\ [[Continue->BB4_1]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $a_fear = "cats">> <<endnobr>> “Birds, totally cool with. Cats, on the other hand, now they will make me scream,” I tell her, waving the thought of a bird scaring me away. “Cats. I mean I can see why someone wouldn’t want to deal with them, but not why they would be afraid,” Sydero continues. “When I was small, one clawed the absolute crap out of me and just hated my guts. I was small and it was dark, and I was terrified. So yes, cats.” Thankfully, Syd doesn’t seem interested in learning any more. Instead, she seems ready to start searching, entering the woods with me right behind her. <<if $cp>>\ [[Continue->BB3_1]] <<else>>\ [[Continue->BB4_1]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $a_fear = "insects">> <<endnobr>> “I actually don’t like insects,” I tell her. “Like, insects in general or just a few?” “In general, really. Butterflies creep me out, I scream at ladybugs, bees make me want to die on the spot. Don’t get me started on wasps and dragonflies.” Sydero snorts as if my fear was actually entertaining, but knowing her it probably was. She begins the walk into the woods, and I begin thinking about all the insects I might run into now. <<if $cp>>\ [[Continue->BB3_1]] <<else>>\ [[Continue->BB4_1]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $a_fear = "spiders">> <<endnobr>> “Yes, I’m pretty sure I’m not afraid of owls. Now, if that were a spider, then it would be a different story.” “What a common fear,” Syd snorts, motioning for me to follow as she walks into the woods. “I’d agree if mine was common. I once accidentally stepped on a black widow’s egg nest when I was a kid,” I’m unable to finish the thought as I shiver, shaking my head at the memories that poke at my brain. My fear wasn’t just, ‘ew, spider,’ I was terrified of the things. <<if $cp>>\ [[Continue->BB3_1]] <<else>>\ [[Continue->BB4_1]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $a_fear = "snakes">> <<endnobr>> “Actually, I’m terrified of snakes,” I tell her, and she raises a brow, “their nature is just creepy, and nasty, and dangerous. And I don’t really have a good memory of them. My uncle and I were hiking when I almost stepped on a rattlesnake.” I shiver at the thought, sighing as I push it back out of my mind. “You would be terrified of the one creature I actually adore,” Syd points out, and I give her an incredulous look. Of course. Of course, she would like the one animal I feared most of all. She motions for me to follow her and we begin our trek through the woods. <<if $cp>>\ [[Continue->BB3_1]] <<else>>\ [[Continue->BB4_1]] <</if>>\Both of us have our phones out, the flashlights on as we look around the area. I keep close to Sydero, shining my light on the side that she wasn’t paying much attention to. “Roe, try calling Chris’s phone. Hopefully, it’s not on vibrate, and we can hear it from here.” I nod at the idea and do as she says. The plan works, and his ringtone gives us the general direction to go in. As we go, we can see the light of some of the nearby houses through peeks in the trees, we were coming back up on the outskirts of the woods. On one hand, that meant we were getting out of the woods, on the other, Chris was over here but for what reason? I call his phone for the third time and hear it nearby, we were practically right next to him. Sydero swivels, flashing her light in the direction and it is there where we find Chris. He’s leaning most of his weight on a tree, his eyes almost glowing in the darkness. His gaze is set on a dog inside an enclosed fence. The dog was currently in its doghouse, and I can only tell that he’s staring at us because of the light shining over him. He looks terrified, and I can’t blame him. “Chris?” I call out, but Chris doesn’t react to my voice, still staring at the dog. His breathing is ragged, and I can tell that some of his clothes are ripped. At least I know he wasn’t dying. “Using common sense here,” Sydero begins, slowly walking towards Chris’s rear, “I’d say he’s transforming, but it’s not complete. It might not be complete until he eats a heart.” “And how do we change him back?” “Usually by killing the thing that turned him. Other times by doing some insane ritual, and sometimes there’s no going back.” I give Sydero a long look, even if she was just trying to inform me, I could do without the last one. I approach Chris slowly, hands out in front as if he was some wild animal that needed to be calmed and tamed. The latter of my thought was probably a stretch, but comparing Chris to a wild animal was not. “How is he changing this quick?” I ask Sydero who keeps her distance, “the thing only scratched him yesterday!” “Bradley might’ve been onto something about the death part. Some creatures are able to quickly spread whatever virus they have to enable transformation since the act itself is rare.” “But the beast is still killing,” I argue. <<if $oldman>>\ “And it was also shot by that old man, remember?” I close my mouth, now wondering if the beast’s life was coming to an end. My eyes drift back over to Chris whose gaze flickers between Sydero and me. <</if>>\ The question that I was most worried about concerned Chris, and how to subdue him. [[Jump him with Sydero.]] [[Coax him to you.]]Both of us have our phones out, the flashlights on as we look around the area. I keep close to Sydero, shining my light on the side that she wasn’t paying much attention to. Looking in the woods for some random girl we’ve never met before, it shouldn’t be that hard, right? I look at Sydero and nod, both of us lunging towards Chris. He shouts, throwing out a fist that instantly connects with my jaw. I shake it off the best I can, which wasn’t good at all. The hangover was still present and, combined with the punch, was scrambling my thoughts. Either he was much stronger than I initally thought he was, or this hangover was making me sensitive – or both. <<else>>\ We creep closer towards him, angling ourselves so that he couldn’t just run off. [[Tackle him.]] [[Hit him with a stick.]] [[Use my shirt to cover his face.]]<<nobr>> <<set $pacifist +=3>> <<endnobr>> “Hey, Syd,” I begin, approaching Chris slowly, “stay back, I’m going to try and bring him back to us.” “You’re going to what?” Syd questions, giving me her usual ‘you’re crazy’ look. “I believe Chris is still in there. If I can just calm him down and get close enough, I can get him.” “Oh, this I have to see.” Syd leans up against a nearby tree, patiently waiting to see how this would go. I slowly approach Chris, talking to him in a soft voice and bringing up past memories, hoping that it will move something inside of him. His attention is still on the dog, but when I get into his personal space, he jerks around to stare at me. His pupils were beginning to turn into slits, and I couldn't help but feel like I was losing him. “Come on, Chris, there’s no way you went full beast on me just yet,” I say, taking another cautious step towards him. I was now directly in front of him. “Chris?” I question. He blinks once, then twice, and then rapid fire. It looks like the haziness in his eyes clear up, and he tilts his head to the side slightly, his mouth parting. Abruptly, he reaches for me and with all of his might, pushes me into a tree that is a few feet away. “And there it goes,” Syd chuckles from her spot, Chris charging towards me. [[Move so he hits the tree.]] [[Tell Syd to come help me.]]I mimic Syd’s laughing, taking a step away from the tree at the right moment so that Chris ends up running into it. I hear the loud thud and shake my head at the pain that would’ve caused any sane person to be in enormous discomfort. Chris rests on the ground, still, and his eyes closed. “Nice, Roe. I can’t wait till he wakes up and questions how he got that knot on his forehead,” Syd smirks, and I glance down to see one beginning to form precisely where she says. “I’ll just blame it on you.” “Despite how funny that is, I won’t claim it. And that’ll probably be enough evidence for him to know it was your fault.” I grumble underneath my breath. “Let’s get this guy back to the car and then to Bradley,” Syd begins, grabbing him and supporting his left side. I go to the right, and we both quickly retrace our steps back, pausing when we hear growling in the nearby bushes. “Uh, that doesn’t sound like it’s some cute little forest animal who wants to be pet,” I gulp, repositioning Chris’s limp form. “That’s because it’s not,” Sydero hisses in reply, “run.” The two of us take off, constantly repositioning Chris and then having to slow down for the other as we go. We don’t get far when I practically feel something on the back of my neck, and then feel something swipe at my legs. I trip, rolling out of the way as a claw comes down in front of me. My eyes widen as I stare back at the beast, and beast it was. Like all the accounts have said, the creature was large with mangled fur and haunting blue eyes. The entire thing reminded me of a bobcat who was incredibly large and had gotten into it with some barbwire. It rears up, howling as it plans to stomp me into the ground. Just as it does, Sydero flings herself towards it, ramming her shoulder into its side and causing it to fall and skid to the side. “We gotta go,” she tells me, yanking me up to my feet. [[“You grab Chris, I’ll hold it off.”]] [[“I’ll grab Chris, you hold it off.”]]“How about you stop laughing and come help me,” I screech, dodging his fist and running to the side. He immediately changes his direction and comes after me again. “Syd!” Before Chris can get to me again, he trips and hits the forest floor with a loud thump, hopefully, there were no rocks nearby. Syd stands behind him, putting pressure on one of his pressure points before giving me a look. “Is the little baby okay?” she asks, mimicking the voice a concerned mother would make. “Shut up, but I’m fine, thanks for asking.” “Let’s get this guy back to the car and then to Bradley,” Syd begins, grabbing him and supporting his left side. I stick near trees, running my hands lightly over the grass and dirt. I finally feel something harsh, long, and with a circular base, and pick it up. Yep, it was a stick alright. Albeit, not the thickest or strongest branch, but it was going to have to be enough for now. I find Chris and Sydero still grappling. I’m reminded of the two sparring, Chris never coming close to being able to land a hit on Syd. Syd would continuously point out that Chris was better long distance, calling him a goner in hand to hand combat. But here he was, holding his own. It was because of the foreign blood shooting through his veins, but visually it was still Chris. I shake the thought away, creeping closer. This stick wasn’t thick enough to get multiple hits in. I would have to do one good one and hope it was enough. He comes closer, and I take the hit, hitting the back of his head. One arm keeps Chris secure while the other fiddles with my phone, lighting my way. Behind me, I hear the sound of shots being fired and a mix between a roar and a whimper. I find my way through the woods, happy when I can see the brightness of a nearby light post. I spot the car and make a dash towards it. “Ugh,” I hear Chris moan, oh great, he was beginning to wake up. [[Knock him back out.->BBKO]] [[Keep running.]]<<nobr>> <<set $guns +=5>> <<endnobr>> I grab my gun and check the cartridge and then take it off of safety, taking multiple breaths as I get ready. It does the same, its gaze is drawn to the gun. It sounds like it’s grumbling as it begins to circle me. Once its eyes meet mine, it charges. I fire two rounds into it, wanting to see how it would react to that. The hit doesn’t do anything though, it just keeps coming, as if I hadn’t even shot at it. Good thing I just needed to buy some time, not actually kill the creature. Also, this was proof that silver bullets weren’t doing anything. It gets too close for comfort, and I roll to the side, cursing to myself when I remember that I was outside amongst sticks and rocks and other such things. “Roe!” I hear Sydero shout and after firing two more shots, aimed at its face, take off. <<if $hangover>>\ Sydero was right, fear was a hell of a cure to a hangover. <</if>>\ <<if $cp>>\ “Let’s go,” Syd encourages, getting into the car, no questions asked. [[Get in the car and drive back to the motel.]] [[Go back in and handle the beast.]] <<else>>\ “Don’t have to tell me twice, let’s go!” I shout, quickly hopping into the car and then speeding away. I forget that we’re still in a residential area and I book it, probably going sixty. Whatever gets us out of there faster. We arrive at the motel about ten minutes after leaving the park. The girl was just now waking up from being knocked out, and by the way she was fighting the restraints Syd put on her, we were probably going to have to knock her out again. “Who knew teens could be so rowdy,” Syd growls, dragging her out of the car, but then letting her go after almost kicking her in the gut. I flinch at the sound of her body hitting the ground, though it seems she felt nothing. She thrashes and fights her restraints. I grab her legs while Syd grabs her shoulders, “she is a lot feistier now, huh?” I question, grimacing as she attempts to wrestle her legs back, but I refuse her this luxury. We get her into the room without further incident. I was planning on putting her on the bed, but Sydero had other plans. As soon as we’re near a corner, she lets go of her, abandoning the girl and joining Bradley who's staring from us to the girl. [[Continue->BB4_2]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $blades +=5>> <<endnobr>> I bring out my blade, twirling it around and then regretting it a second later, I wasn’t quite there yet. Putting my attention back on the beast, it charges without any consideration for the weapon now in my grasp. The reach of the blade wasn’t tremendous, it was about the same length, if not just a tad bit shorter as a short sword. The beast is upon me, swiping its paw towards me and I swing my blade. My blade skids across its paw, creating a deep gash that the creature doesn’t appreciate. It whimpers, its eyes blazing with new hatred for me. It charges again, this time barreling towards me, shoulder first. I time my jump, jumping out of the way and sliding my blade down its flank as I go. It turns around, and I narrowly avoid its claws. “Roe!” I hear Sydero shout and immediately take off into a sprint, didn’t have to tell me twice. <<if $hangover>>\ Sydero was right, fear was a hell of a cure to a hangover. <</if>>\ <<if $cp>>\ “Let’s go,” Syd encourages, getting into the car, no questions asked. [[Get in the car and drive back to the motel.]] [[Go back in and handle the beast.]] <<else>>\ “Don’t have to tell me twice, let’s go!” I shout, quickly hopping into the car and then speeding away. I forget that we’re still in a residential area and I book it, probably going sixty. Whatever gets us out of there faster. We arrive at the motel about ten minutes after leaving the park. The girl was just now waking up from being knocked out, and by the way she was fighting the restraints Syd put on her, we were probably going to have to knock her out again. “Who knew teens could be so rowdy,” Syd growls, dragging her out of the car, but then letting her go after almost kicking her in the gut. I flinch at the sound of her body hitting the ground, though it seems she felt nothing. She thrashes and fights her restraints. I grab her legs while Syd grabs her shoulders, “she is a lot feistier now, huh?” I question, grimacing as she attempts to wrestle her legs back, but I refuse her this luxury. We get her into the room without further incident. I was planning on putting her on the bed, but Sydero had other plans. As soon as we’re near a corner, she lets go of her, abandoning the girl and joining Bradley who's staring from us to the girl. [[Continue->BB4_2]] <</if>>\<<if $cp>>\ <<nobr>> <<set $knockoutchris = true>> <<endnobr>> I pause and put him down, mumbling a short apology as I put all my energy into the punch. At least, that’s how the movies and video games always knock out opponents. I guess it works since Chris is quiet once again. If he asks who, I’ll just blame it on Sydero, or him hallucinating. I grab him and go back to running, calling for Sydero as loud as I can. <<if $hangover>>\ Sydero was right, fear was a hell of a cure to a hangover. <</if>>\ “Let’s go,” Syd encourages, getting into the car, no questions asked. [[Get in the car and drive back to the motel.]] [[Go back in and handle the beast.]] <<else>>\ <<nobr>> <<set $knockoutgirl = true>> <<endnobr>> I pause and put her down, mumbling a short apology as I put all my energy into the punch. [[Continue->BB4_2]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $motel = true>> <<endnobr>> “Don’t have to tell me twice, let’s go!” I shout, quickly hopping into the car and then speeding away. I forget that we’re still in a residential area and I book it, probably going sixty. Whatever gets us out of there faster. We arrive at the motel about ten minutes after leaving the park. Chris was just now waking up from being knocked out, and by the way he was fighting the restraints Syd put on him, we were probably going to have to knock him out again. “Who knew your friend could be so rowdy,” Syd growls, dragging him out of the car, but then letting him go as he almost kicks her in the gut. I flinch at the sound of his body hitting the ground, though it seems he felt nothing. He thrashes and fights his restraints, no sign of Chris there. <<if $CRomance >=3>>\ I grab his legs while Syd grabs his shoulders, “well,” I smirk, giving her a knowing look. “Nope, not what I meant. I was planning on putting him on the bed, but Sydero had other plans. As soon as we’re near a corner, she lets go of him, abandoning him and joining Bradley who calls us over. <<if $sympathy >= 50>>\ “Can you be a little more careful with him?” I scowl at Sydero. “No, I really can’t. What do you have for us, Bradley?” <<else>>\ “What do you have for us, Bradley?” Syd asks once she gets to his side. <</if>>\ “I think I finally realized what’s going on. What’s going on with Chris, BB, and everything really.” “Hold up, hold up,” Sydero interrupts, her face scrunching up in confusion, “BB?” “Yea, Bladenboro Beast, BB.” <<if $serious >= 50>>\ “Can we get back to the subject, please?” I groan, rolling my eyes and motioning for him to continue. <<else>>\ “Very creative, Bradley,” I chuckle, motioning for him to continue. <</if>>\ “I think BB is – well, parenting Chris. I was able to get on the dark web and look deeper. Which is saying a lot cos there was still literally nothing even on the dark web. Anyway, I found that the beast before this one was said to have yellow eyes and a white mark on its chest, this one obviously not fitting that description. BB seems to pop up, hunt, someone goes missing, and then it disappears again. What if the people it ends up changing, it ends up taking a mothering role over them? Teaching them to survive and what not?” “So, BB just wants to be a parent, I still don’t see why it decides to go on a pet killing spree and then turn some random person,” Sydero points out, “plus, we’ve only run into one of these things, what happened to the one with yellow eyes?” “I was wondering the exact same thing,” Bradley continues, “and this is more of a hypothesis than a fact, but what if it’s killing to feed whoever it ends up transforming? Remember my death idea, what if it goes after someone when it knows its life is coming to an end, and the last thing it does is teach and parent this person? Pets are easy prey, so it goes after them to make sure the transforming person has food.” [[“BB’s parenting is highly flawed.”]] [[“So is this how BB ... breeds?”]] [[“But how do we stop it?”]]<<nobr>> <<set $afterhim = true>> <<endnobr>> I bite the side of my cheek, looking back towards the woods where the beast is still probably at. “Hold up, Syd, I think we should go and handle the beast. We have a perfect window.” She opens her door and turns to me. “Chris is in the back seat, dying, and you want to go ‘handle’ the beast. We need to secure him.” “It’s stupid to just let the beast run off, especially when we’re this close.” “When did I start caring more about Chris’s life than you?” she questions, cocking her head to the side in interest. “This is for Chris,” I say, “that creature, whether through death or something else, holds the answer to getting Chris back. Are you seriously saying we should just leave?” “No, what I’m saying is that it’s stupid to handle two crazies at the same time. We make sure that crazy is secure, and then focus on that one.” I begin to argue her point further when a loud roar pierces our ears. We both glance in the direction to see the beast charging out of the woods and towards us. “Doesn’t seem to matter anymore,” Sydero growls when suddenly Chris hops onto her back, bringing her to the ground. “Who do I go for?” I question aloud, actually wanting an answer from Syd, but I receive nothing but the roar from the beast, and grunts from Sydero as she tries to grab Chris. Guess I was making this decision. [[Go after the beast.]] [[Go after Chris.]]<<if $cp>>\ “I don’t know what you guys are thinking, but BB’s parenting is highly flawed. I mean, for starters, it kinda involves kidnapping.” “I don’t think BB cares about what you think of his ... hers ... its parenting skills,” Sydero assures me, and I notice that she’s pacing back and forth, “this is all interesting, but we have no idea how to kill BB, or how to turn Chris back.” My eyes venture over to him, relatively peaceful even though he’s not knocked out. <<if $afterhim>>\ “Try iron, one of the sites said that the hunters from a while ago said that they used weapons made of it,” Bradley informs us, “as for Chris, it doesn’t say anything about it, but I have an idea. It requires your help, Syd.” She grumbles, rolling her eyes. I’m sure if she were near a tree or wall, she would be hitting her head against it. “Of course you do, does it require keeping BB alive?” “Yes,” Bradley squeaks. “Ugh, tell me the plan.” <<else>>\ “Try iron, one of the sites said that the hunters from a while ago said that they used weapons made of it,” Bradley informs us, “as for Chris, it doesn’t say anything about it, but I have an idea. It requires your help, Syd.” She grumbles, rolling her eyes and walking towards the window, moving the blinds to peer out of it. “Of course you do, does it require keeping BB alive?” “Yes,” Bradley squeaks. “Well then, we just need to find it again,” I say, huffing, not exactly ready to face that monstrosity a second time. “No need, it found us,” Sydero tells us, still looking out the window. Oh geez. <</if>>\ [[Act Three->EP7-Act Three]] <<else>>\ “I don’t know what you guys are thinking, but BB’s parenting is highly flawed. I mean for starters, it kinda involves kidnapping.” “I don’t think BB cares about what you think of his ... hers ... its parenting skills,” Sydero assures me, and I notice that she’s pacing back and forth, “this is all interesting, but we have no idea how to kill BB, or how to turn this girl back.” My eyes venture over to her, relatively peaceful even though she’s not knocked out. She hugs the blanket close to her, her eyes on us. “Try iron, one of the sites said that the hunters from a while ago said that they used weapons made of it,” Bradley informs us, “as for her –” “Winfrey,” the girl squeaks. We each freeze, gazing over at her as she readjusts herself in the blanket. “My name is Winfrey.” “How long have you been sane?” Syd asks with an accusatory tone, earning a sharp tap across the head from Bradley. “Long enough to hear you guys call me girl numerous of times. I ... I know what you guys did for me in the woods too, you helped me but –” she growls, suddenly she clenches her head, moaning in agony. “What’s happening to me?” I look at the other two, wondering if any of them were going to tell her. Before any of us can tell her, what was going on with her, she screams again, pointing to the door and backing away, “it’s coming. It’s mad at you, it’s mad that you keep trying to keep me from it.” Her eyes go wide, and she clutches her head, when she looks back at us, I don’t see Winfrey anymore, I see whatever I fought back in the woods. We each freeze, gazing over at her as she readjusts herself in the blanket. “My name is Winfrey.” “How long have you been sane?” Syd asks with an accusatory tone, earning a sharp tap across the head from Bradley. “Long enough to hear you guys call me girl numerous of times. I ... Oh geez. [[Act Three->EP7-Act Three]] <</if>>\<<nobr>> <<set $heartsonfire = false>> <<endnobr>> <<link [img[images/actthree.png]] >><</link>> <<if $motel>>\ <<if $cp>>\ I join Sydero by the window, looking across the street at BB. I swear BB’s staring right back at us, its blue eyes raging with fury at what we stole from it. Though, it took Chris from us first, so I lack any sympathy. “Exactly what do you have planned, Bradley?” I question, turning to him. His eyes are on Chris who is now twitching in his spot, fighting against the binds that hold him. “It will have me,” he cries, tears running down his eyes as he struggles, “you must let me go. Let me go to it!” “If I didn’t know better, I’d say we'd already lost Chris,” Syd remarks, grabbing her gun and checking it. Chris’s eyes widen, and he lets out a low roar, thrashing even more. “This does prove our point about BB being a parent figure,” Bradley tells us, “obviously Chris is feeling some kind of connection to it.” “Bradley, focus. What’s the plan here?” I question, tearing my eyes from Chris’s figure and back to BB, noticing that it’s prowling the outskirts of the parking lot. “Syd, you need to use a –” Bradley’s eyes go from me to her, “an empathy spell. BB’s top motivation obviously has to do with Chris so we might be able to figure out how to reverse whatever it is by figuring out what BB is trying to stop us from doing. $name, you need to help her with subduing BB.” “What’s the plan then?” Syd asks me, opening the door and facing off against BB, “it’s already injured, we just need to do enough to put it down, but not kill it, not until I can figure out what I need.” [[Wing it.]] <<if $sympathy >= 50>>\ [[Ask Chris for help.]] <</if>>\ <<if $sympathy < 50 or $honesty < 50>>\ [[Catch it unaware, using Chris.]] <</if>>\ <<else>>\ Sydero and I both approach the window, looking across the street and, sure enough, seeing BB standing there. I swear BB’s staring right back at us, its blue eyes raging with fury at what we stole from it. “Exactly what do you have planned, Bradley?” I question, turning to him. His eyes are on Winfrey who is now twitching in her spot, fighting against the binds that hold her. “It will have me,” she cries, tears running down her eyes as she struggles, “you must let me go. Let me go to it!” I’m about to turn back to the others when she suddenly screeches, “no. Don’t let it get me.” She cries, hard enough for snot to seep out of her nose. “So, before this gets anymore disgusting than it already is, plan?” Syd questions, grabbing her gun and checking it. Winfrey’s eyes widen, and she lets out a low roar, thrashing even more. “This does prove our point about BB being a parent figure,” Bradley tells us, “obviously Winfrey is feeling some kind of connection to it.” “Bradley, focus. What’s the plan here?” I question, tearing my eyes from the girl’s figure and back to BB, noticing that it’s prowling the outskirts of the parking lot. “Syd, you need to use a –,” Bradley’s eyes go from me to her, “an empathy spell. BB’s top motivation obviously has to do with Winfrey so we might be able to figure out how to reverse whatever it is by figuring out what BB is trying to stop us from doing. $name, you need to help her with subduing BB.” I raise a brow when Syd doesn’t argue, stating that she needs no help. I keep her lack of quarreling to myself, for now. “What’s the plan then?” Syd asks me, opening the door and facing off against BB, “it’s already injured, we just need to do enough to put it down, but not kill it, not until I can figure out what I need.” [[Wing it.]] <<if $sympathy >= 50>>\ [[Ask Winfrey for help.]] <</if>>\ <<if $sympathy < 50 or $honesty < 50>>\ [[Catch it unaware, using Winfrey.]] <</if>>\ <</if>>\ <<else>>\ We run through the woods, attempting to catch sight of Chris or the beast. We fail to see them, but we hear them easily. The whimpers of the creature and what I can only believe is Chris’s labored breathing. “Stop, slow down,” Sydero suddenly directs, putting her hand out in front of me and getting down. The whimpering of the beast is gone, but we both hear something else, something that we don’t exactly know. And not only that, but a horrible smell intrudes our noses, causing both of us to want to gag. Crouched, we continue forward until we get a better view of what’s going on. A sizeable makeshift nest has been built out of rocks, twigs, and leaves. In the middle sits the bodies of all the dead animals that we had heard about. The decomposing bodies are surrounded by flying insects, enjoying the buffet. “Well, I think we found the animals,” Sydero whispers harshly, looking around for something else. I tug her sleeve and point to the side where the beast rests. It lays on its side, whimpering quietly as it licks a collection of wounds. Chris is sitting off to the side, curled up in a fetal position. He gasps and kicks, and upon further investigation, I can hear him struggling to grasp his situation. “Help me,” I hear him cry out weakly, “$name.” I barely make out him saying my name, but it’s enough to make me move closer. Sydero grabs my arm, raising a brow at my involuntary action. “So, we stick with the plan we made back there?” I question, and she nods decisively, creeping away from me and closer towards the beast. The plan called for me to subdue Chris while Sydero did a ritual to look into BB’s motivations. Bradley was hoping that an empathy spell would tell us what we were searching for, therefore learning how to turn Chris back. I don’t know how long this ritual would take Sydero, but I was to make sure Chris didn’t do anything to jeopardize us turning him back. This mostly meant eating any of the spoiled hearts sitting not too far off. I stay where I am when Sydero flies out of the bushes, past the barricade that BB had set up, and towards BB’s hulking frame. BB stands up to roar, leaving its midsection open for Sydero’s blade to easily cut the fur and flesh that rests there. BB looks to Chris, and I suppose in cryptid language, orders him to do something, because the next thing I know, Chris is rushing toward the pile of putrid hearts. “Oh no you don’t,” I shout, dashing for Chris. As soon as I’m near him, he turns and kicks me straight in the gut. I bend over, a lack of breath making it to my lungs as my body tries to figure out what had just happened. Before I can overthink it, Chris picks up a stick and swings it at my head. I jump back, and he approaches. [[Set fire to the hearts.]] [[Subdue Chris.]] [[Prompt Chris to chase you.]] <</if>>\Sydero was handling Chris, which meant that I should probably put my attention on the beast. It heads for Sydero, and so I pick up a large rock, chucking it straight at its head. Its head whips towards me, its path changing but then it comes to a complete halt, its attention going back to Sydero and Chris. The beast does a long call before turning and cantering back into the woods, Chris following behind it as it goes. The two disappearing and neither Sydero nor I follow. [[Continue->BB3_2]]I turn my attention to Chris, if I could get his attention on me, then Sydero could focus on the beast. I pick up a rock and throw it at him. His eyes blaze with fury as he looks over at me, the slowly rising sun not helping the murderous glint in his slit-styled eyes. “Syd, wanna handle the beast?” I ask. “No, I want to get out of here,” she growls but sprints towards the beast, grabbing her blade. She skids, swinging the blade right as the creature gets into striking distance. She could handle herself, I needed to handle Chris. He stalks around me, his posture twisted to mirror that of the beast. I pause at that. I had just fought him a few minutes ago, and this wasn’t his fighting style. Chris swipes at me, getting two good hits that send me to the ground. The beast does a long call before turning and cantering back into the woods, Chris following behind it as it goes. The two disappearing and neither Sydero nor I follow. [[Continue->BB3_2]]<<nobr>> <<set $answer1 to "teaching">> <<endnobr>> “And we lost both of them, again,” Sydero mutters, helping me to my feet. She lightly hits me upside the head, “have I told you how much I hate your plans? Because I do, I really do.” It wasn't like I expected Chris to run off after the beast as if he was some obedient little pup, following behind his master. Before I’m able to say anything, my phone rings and I look to see that it’s Bradley. “You call me to tell me how much you hate my plans too?” I give Sydero a look, and she matches it with one of her own. “Um no, should I ... whatever, I called because I think I finally realized what’s going on. What’s going on with Chris, BB, and everything, really.” “Hold up, hold up,” Sydero starts, “BB?” “Yea, Bladenboro Beast, BB.” “Very, creative Bradley, but I think I know exactly what’s going on here,” I begin to tell him, “the beast is ...” //The answer is a single word and ends in ‘ing.’// <<textbox "$answer1" "">> [[Continue->BB3_3]] <<if $answer1.toLowerCase().includes("teaching")>>\ <<nobr>> <<set $bradley +=5>> <<set $sydero +=5>> <<set $supernatural +=5>> <<endnobr>> “I realized it when Chris attacked me the second time, his posture mirrored that of ... BB. And then it got me thinking about how we found the beast and Chris in the same area, how Chris looked like he was hunting that dog and the beast was nearby. The beast, for whatever reason, is parenting Chris, teaching him how to survive.” “Bradley?” Sydero questions, stroking her chin as she thinks about my words, but seems to also want a second opinion. “I’ve come to the same conclusion, well not because of Chris’s mannerisms, but due to the pattern. I was able to get on the dark web and look deeper. Which is saying a lot because there was still literally nothing on even the dark web. Anyway, I found that the beast before this one was said to have yellow eyes and a white mark on its chest, this one obviously not fitting that description. BB seems to pop up, hunt, someone goes missing, and then it disappears again.” <<else>>\ “... yea, I don’t know.” “I’m surrounded by idiots,” Sydero mumbles, “Bradley?” “I think BB is – well, parenting Chris. I was able to get on the dark web and look deeper. Which is saying a lot cos there was still literally nothing even on the dark web. Anyway, I found that the beast before this one was said to have yellow eyes and a white mark on its chest, this one obviously not fitting that description. BB seems to pop up, hunt, someone goes missing, and then it disappears again. What if the people it ends up changing, it ends up taking a mothering role over them? Teaching them to survive and what not?” <</if>>\ “So, BB just wants to be a parent, I still don’t see why it decides to go on a pet killing spree and then turn some random person. Plus, we’ve only run into one of these things, what happened to the one with yellow eyes?” “I was wondering the exact same thing,” Bradley continues, “and this is more of a hypothesis than a fact, but what if it’s killing to feed whoever it ends up transforming? Remember my death idea, what if it goes after someone when it knows its life is coming to an end, and the last thing it does is teach and parent this person? Pets are easy prey, so it goes after them to make sure the, transforming person has food.” [[“BB’s parenting is highly flawed.”]] [[“So is this how BB ... breeds?”]] [[“But how do we stop it?”]] “I object,” I suddenly say, that’s not what I was trying to say. Bradley looks at me in worry while Sydero just looks amused, she was definitely going to bring me on her bar trips more often, “I mean, I don’t think I’m sane enough for this.” “I second that,” Bradley says, but Syd waves his worries away. “I don’t see why we need to go investigate this in the first place,” she points out, “I see no relation to the supernatural we’re hunting.” “Oh, I forgot that I haven’t told you guys what I also found. I think I know what you’ve been after this entire time.” “Well?” I question. “There’s a legend around it that might either be true or not, but the locals call it the Bladenboro Beast.” Bradley gets quiet, probably wanting his words to sink in. “Not very creative if you ask me,” Sydero mumbles, “what else did you learn?” “Not much. Legend says that the beast is some large creature that feeds on animal hearts. A couple of years ago it was attacking and those that claim to have seen it always claim that it’s massive, walks on all fours, have blue eyes, and sharp fangs. Everyone thought that they killed it when the locals killed a cougar and the killing stopped, but no one was one-hundred percent sure.” [[“So, why did the killings stop?”]] [[“So, is it a werecat or not?”]]We march to the outskirts of the familiar woods, stopping there. “Those are some pretty big woods, we might not be able to find her so easily,” Sydero starts, curling up her lips in disgust, “Bladenboro Beast, I hate local cryptids.” “Why?” “I know how to put a werewolf or vampire down, but local cryptids are always a special case. Your only source of information about them is local and you gotta hope there’s enough to go off of.” She grabs her unique blade and expertly tosses it a short distance into the air, admiring it, “luckily most supernaturals die or at least are injured by silver.” I hear an owl in the distance, jumping into Syd as I tell myself to calm down. Woods and I didn’t have a good track record, and the last thing I wanted to do was go into them at night to find my crazed best friend and some local cryptid. “Chill, Roe, you can’t tell me you’re afraid of an owl.” “Of course not,” I huff. “You sure?” [[“I actually am kinda scared of birds.”]] <<if $doglike isnot true>>\ [[“No, I'm terrified of dogs.”]] <</if>>\ <<if $catlike isnot true>>\ [[“Birds I'm fine with, it's cats that make me scream.”]] <</if>>\ [[“I actually don’t like insects.”]] [[“Yes, now if that was a spider, it’s a different story.”]] [[“I’m terrified of snakes actually.”]]“Heck no! Are you crazy? The first rule to a horror movie, never split up, come on Syd, you’re better than this,” I scold her, and she holds her hand up in surrender. “I’m just trying to find this chick faster. We’re never going to find her this way.” “I’d rather not find her at all than to find her and be by myself when I do.” With the matter put to rest, we continue on. We get closer to the outskirts of the nearby houses, seeing some of their backyard lights from where we were. I’m about to travel closer when we both hear someone snap a branch, the sound of a dog whimpering follows behind that. I get down, making my way towards the sound when I see the girl. It was the pre-teen from earlier, the one that had her dog taken away from her. She’s leaning most of her weight on a tree, her blue eyes almost glowing in the darkness. Due to my phone light still being on, I also realize that she’s practically naked, only a bra and underwear hiding her extremities. Her gaze is set on a dog inside an enclosed fence. The dog was currently in its house, and I can only tell that he’s staring at us because of the light shining over him. He looks petrified, and I can’t blame him. “Um, girl?” I call out, never getting her name, but needing to catch her attention. She doesn’t respond to my voice, still staring at the dog, her breathing ragged. “Using common sense here,” Sydero begins, slowly walking towards the girl’s rear, “I’d say she’s transforming, but it’s not complete. It might not be complete until she eats a heart.” “And how do we change her back?” “Usually by killing the thing that turned her. Other times by doing some insane ritual, and sometimes there’s no going back.” I give Sydero a long look, even if she was just trying to inform me, I could do without the last one. I approach the girl slowly, hands out in front as if she was some wild animal that needed to be calmed and tamed. The latter of my thought was probably a stretch but comparing her to a wild animal was not. “How is she changing this quick?” I ask Sydero who keeps her distance, “the thing only scratched her yesterday afternoon!” “Bradley might’ve been onto something about the death part. Some creatures are able to quickly spread whatever virus they have to enable transformation since the act itself is rare.” “But the beast is still killing,” I argue. <<if $oldman>>\ “And it was also shot by that old man, remember?” I close my mouth, now wondering if the beast’s life was coming to an end. My eyes drift back over to the preteen whose gaze now flickers between Sydero and me. <</if>>\ The question that I was most worried about concerned the girl, and how to subdue her. “Alright, let's move in, both of us,” I tell her, and she nods, moving in a step more. “Shouldn’t be too hard, right?” Syd asks, “she’s just a little girl.” <<if $hangover>>\ We creep closer towards her, angling ourselves so that she couldn’t just run off. I look at Sydero and nod, both of us lunging towards the girl. She lets out a feral cry and throws punches left and right at me, out of the fifteen she throws, one actually connects. It sends me reeling and, combined with my still present hangover, triples the pain. Either she was much stronger than I initially thought, or this hangover was making me sensitive – or both. <<else>>\ We creep closer towards her, angling ourselves so that she couldn’t just run off. I look at Sydero and nod, both of us lunging towards the girl. She lets out a feral cry and throws punches left and right at me, out of the fifteen she throws, one actually connects. It sends me reeling, my jaw aching as the pain slowly begins to fade. <</if>>\ “Stop messing around Roe,” Sydero shouts, barely fast enough to dodge the girl’s attack. Not only was she looking feral, but she was fighting as if she was some type of cornered prey. One minute she was fighting like a human, the next she was slashing with her nails. [[Tackle her.]] [[Hit her with a stick.]] [[Use my shirt to cover her face.]]<<nobr>> <<set $split = true>> <<endnobr>> “Yea, maybe we should. We’ll cover more ground that way. I guess we could yell when we got something?” I ask her, and she snorts, already walking off. <<if $SRomance >= 3>>\ “I don’t yell, Roe,” she smirks and turns back to me, her eyes glancing up and down my body, “that’s something I do to others.” My mouth flattens into a thin line as she chuckles, her and her light disappearing. <<else>>\ “I don’t yell, Roe, it’s not my style,” she tells me and then shakes her phone, “I’ll just call you. Like a normal person.” I roll my eyes, I have definitely heard her yell before, but whatever floats her sinking boat I suppose. <</if>>\ I continue on, on my own now, realizing that the absence of Sydero’s light was making it much harder to see my surroundings. I see the hint of light in the distance, peaking through the trees and I follow it immediately. The outline of houses appears, and I realize that the light that I allowed to guide me, were basic backyard lights. Either way, it was a much-needed source, and I stick close to the outskirts of the woods as I continue looking. I hear a branch snap, thinking it to be Sydero, when I then hear a dog whimpering. Unless Sydero was forcing some poor dog into listening to how emotionless she was, I doubt it was her. I get down, making my way towards the sound when I see the girl. It was the pre-teen from earlier, the one that had her dog taken away from her. She’s leaning most of her weight on a tree, her blue eyes almost glowing in the darkness. Due to my phone light still being on, I also realize that she’s practically naked, only a bra and underwear hiding her extremities. Her gaze is set on a dog inside an enclosed fence. The dog was currently in its house, and I can only tell that he’s staring at us because of the light shining over him. He looks petrified, and I can’t blame him. “Um, girl?” I call out, never getting her name, but needing to catch her attention. She doesn’t respond to my voice, still staring at the dog, her breathing ragged. I continue to approach her slowly, hands out in front as if she was some wild animal that needed to be calmed and tamed. The latter of my thought was probably a stretch but comparing her to a wild animal was not. //How was she changing this quick//, I ask myself, seeing that the beast had only scratched her yesterday afternoon. This question and many more would have to be pushed to the side for now. I was more worried about the girl and how to subdue her. <<if $hangover>>\ I creep closer towards her, speaking in a low voice to not scare her off. I was really going after this wild animal angle. Once I’m close enough, I lunge towards the girl. She lets out a feral cry and throws punches left and right at me, out of the fifteen she throws, one actually connects. It sends me reeling, and combined with my still present hangover, triples the pain. Either she was much stronger than I initially thought, or this hangover was making me sensitive – or both.<<else>>\ I creep closer towards her, speaking in a low voice to not scare her off. I was really going after this wild animal angle. Once I’m close enough, I lunge towards the girl. She lets out a feral cry and throws punches left and right at me, out of the fifteen she throws, one actually connects. It sends me reeling, my jaw aching as the pain slowly begins to fade. <</if>>\ Great, not only was she feral but she was fighting as if she was some kind of cornered prey. I move my jaw around and glare at the woman, trying to figure out what to do. [[Tackle her.]] [[Hit her with a stick.]] [[Use my shirt to cover her face.]]I didn’t really have any good ideas, none of them were bound to work anyway. The best plan I could think of that could actually bring her down, was tackling her. And that’s precisely what I do. I leap forward, grabbing the girl around the waist and letting gravity do the rest. Underneath me, she fights and struggles to get up, but I’m sitting on her back, trying to keep her down with all of my weight. <<if $split>>\ I suddenly hear a loud whimper, followed by a furious roar in the distance. I do believe Sydero found the beast. I was surprised that it was so close. Were it and the girl hunting the same thing? I scoop the preteen into my arms, taking off towards the car. I’m sure Sydero could handle the beast, and if she couldn’t then she was smart enough to know where to run. I find my way through the woods, happy when I can see the brightness of a nearby light post. I spot the car and make a dash towards it. “Ugh,” I hear the young woman moan, oh great, she was beginning to wake up. [[Knock her back out.->BBKO]] [[Keep running.]] <<else>>\ “So, what do we do with her?” I ask Syd, staring down at her limp form. “Normally, I’d say we should bring her to the motel, so we can figure out how to change her back. But I don’t think I want to risk getting caught by police.” “Do we have any other choice?” I ask next, personally not being able to think of anything else. “I don’t think we do, especially since we don’t know how to change her back yet.” Sydero sighs scooping the young girl into her arms. I lead the way out of the woods, pausing when I hear growling in the nearby bushes. “Uh, that doesn’t sound like it’s some cute little forest animal who wants to be pet,” I gulp. “That’s because it’s not,” Sydero hisses in reply, “run.” The two of us take off, Sydero slowing down regularly due to having to readjust the preteen in her arms. I take up the rear to ensure their safety when I practically feel something on the back of my neck, and then feel something swipe at my legs. I trip, rolling out of the way as a claw comes down in front of me. My eyes widen as I stare back at the beast, and beast it was. Like all the accounts have said, the creature was large with mangled fur and haunting blue eyes. The entire thing reminded me of a bobcat who was incredibly large and had gotten into it with some barbwire. It rears up, howling as it plans to stomp me into the ground. Just as it does, Sydero flings herself towards it, ramming her shoulder into its side and causing it to fall and skid to the side. “We gotta go,” she tells me, yanking me up to my feet. [[“You grab her, I’ll hold it off.”]] [[“I’ll grab her, you hold it off.”]] <</if>>\I need a weapon. It was still too dark outside for me to be able to see anything clearly, and so I rely mostly on touch. I stick near trees, running my hands lightly over the grass and dirt. I finally feel something harsh, long, and with a circular base, and pick it up. Yep, it was a stick alright. Albeit, not the thickest or strongest branch, but it was going to have to be enough for now. <<if $split>>\ I shake the thought away, creeping closer. This stick wasn’t thick enough to get multiple hits in. I would have to do one good one and hope it was enough. She comes closer, and I take the hit, hitting the back of her head. The stick breaks immediately on contact, and the girl goes down without a problem. I go towards her limp body when I hear a loud whimper, followed by a furious roar in the distance. What’s going on with her, BB, and everything, really.” “Hold up, hold up,” Sydero interrupts, her face scrunching up in confusion, “BB?” “Yea, Bladenboro Beast, BB, try to keep up here.” <<if $serious >= 50>>\ “Can we get back to the subject, please?” I groan, rolling my eyes and motioning for him to continue. <<else>>\ “Very creative, Bradley,” I chuckle, motioning for him to continue. <</if>>\ “I think BB is – well, parenting this girl. I was able to get on the dark web and look deeper. Which is saying a lot cos there was still literally nothing on even the dark web. Anyway, I found that the beast before this one was said to have yellow eyes and a white mark on its chest, this one obviously not fitting that description. BB seems to pop up, hunt, someone goes missing, and then it disappears again. What if the people it ends up changing, it ends up taking a mothering role over them? Teaching them to survive and what not?” “So, BB just wants to be a parent, I still don’t see why it decides to go on a pet killing spree and then turn some random person,” Sydero points out, “plus, we’ve only run into one of these things, what happened to the one with yellow eyes?” “I was wondering the exact same thing,” Bradley continues, “and this is more of a hypothesis than a fact, but what if it’s killing to feed whoever it ends up transforming? Remember my death idea, what if it goes after someone when it knows its life is coming to an end, and the last thing it does is teach and parent this person? Pets are easy prey, so it goes after them to make sure the transforming person has food.” [[“BB’s parenting is highly flawed.”]] [[“So is this how BB ... breeds?”]] [[“But how do we stop it?”]]<<if $cp>>\ “Honestly, I say we wing this. When have plans ever worked out like we hoped?” I question, much to Sydero’s pleasure. She smiles and nods, the two of us closing the motel door as we stare out at BB. BB sniffs the air, grunting in anger as it comes closer. “I really don’t think BB likes us,” I point out, looking out at our surroundings. There were a few parked cars, some random potted plants, and one lamp post. Seeing that I wasn’t about to use the cars as cover, out of fear of messing up my own, I was left with hardly anything else. “Yea? Well, I can’t say I much like it either,” Sydero snorts, holstering her gun and grabbing her blade, “no using guns, it’ll attract too much attention.” Well, there goes any idea of staying at a distance. I mirror her, grabbing my blade as BB charges towards us. Though the sun was barely beginning to light up the sky, it produced enough light for me to see BB and its enormity. I can feel the ground tremble slightly as BB gets closer, enraged at our actions. [[Throw my blade at BB.]] [[Tell Sydero to throw her blade at BB.]] <<else>>\ “Honestly, I say we wing this. When have plans ever worked out like we hoped?” I question, much to Sydero’s pleasure. She smiles and nods, the two of us closing the motel door as we stare out at BB.
